i8 Inverted: -6 (Result is -(n + 1))

Both borrow/reference operators & or &mut create a reference (e.g. a pointer-like data type) to a value with the transferring ownership of that value to the new variable.

  • &expr immutable/shared reference (e.g. &T) which allows for the reading of the value. Mutiple references can exist simultaneously.
  • &mut expr mutable reference (e.g. &mut T) allows for the reading and modification of the value, but only one mutable reference can exist at a time for a given value.

A reference type borrowing of data allows for the temporary access of aforemention data while allowing the original variable owner to retain ownership.
The deference operator * is used to access data stored within a memory location that is pointed to by a pointer or reference point:

  • *ref yields the underlying value, the resulting data type will be T if the reference ref were &T or &mut T.
  • Deferencing a mutable reference, e.g. *mut_ref = new_value; modifies the original data.
  • There are many data types (e.g., Box, String &str) that implement the Deref trait, which grants the ability to automatic dereference (deref coercion) for method calls or implicit use.

An explicit use of a * deference is often needed for a raw access of data from or assignment data to a variable, but the Rust compiler in many cases auto-deferences these cases itself, such as in method calls.

The Rust Ownership System
Rust's ownership system ensures memory safety at compile time without the need for a garbage collector. It enforces strict rules at compile time to prevent common bugs like use-after-free, double-free, data races, and dangling pointers. The following are the core principles of this ownership system:

  1. Every value has exactly one owner: In Rust, every heap-allocated data, or any data that requires cleanup - is owned by a single variable (e.g. variable binding). For example: 
    1     let s:String = String::from("Halo 3"); // The variable "s" owns the String data on the heap-based memory
    As long as the owner variable remains within scope, its associated data will remain valid and accessible.
  2. When the owner goes out of scope, the value is automatically dropped: When the owning variable leaves its scope, Rust automatically calls the Drop trait's drop method and deallocates the memory. 
    1     fn main() {
2         let s:String = String::from("Doom");
3              
4         { // inner code block 
5             
6             // t is valid within the inner code block
7             let t:String::from("Halo Franchise by 343 Industries");
8      
9         } // t goes out of scope here and is dropped, memory is freed
10     
11    }
12
  3. Ownership can be moved (transferred): When data is assigned to another variable - ownership of that data moves from the original variable to the new variable. 
    1     let s1:String = String::from("Shawn Ryan is awesome!"); 
2     let s2:String = s2;  // Ownership moved to s2
3     // println!("{}", s1); // Compile error: ownership of data moved from s1 to s2
4                            // s1 is no longer a valid variable
5
    This "move semantics" is the default for data types that implement neither the Copy or Clone traits. When data is passed into a function as an argument, the passed data is either bitwise copied or its ownership is moved to the positional argument that it is assigned to.
    • Copy is a marker trait that can only be implemented for data types that
      • A data type that is stored entirely on the stack and is not heap allocated.
      • A data type that does not implement the Drop trait (or any cleanup logic).
      • A data type that is cheap and safe to duplicate via simple bitwise copy.
    • Common data types that implement the Copy trait:
      • All integer data types: i8, i32, u64, usize, et cetera.
      • Floating-point: f32 and f64
      • bool data type.
      • char data type.
      • Both tuples and arrays that contain only Copy trait implemented data types (e.g., (i32, bool), [u8; 32]).
      • References such as &T, but not mutable references &mut T.
    • Common data types that do not implement the Copy trait (and thus move ownership from itself to the positional argument within the function when passed through):
      • String, Vec, Box, these are most of the heap-allocated data types.
      • Custom structs unless explicitly derived with the derive marco #[derive(Copy, Clone)] (and all fields of the struct contain data types that implement the Copy trait).
    1     fn main() {
2         // data type that implement copy trait 
3         let x:i32 = 42;
4         takes_copy(x); 
5         println!("x is still {}", x); // Ownership did not move, so it works.
6             
7         // data type that does not implement copy trait
8         let s:String = String::from("hello"); // variable s is the owner of the string data
9         takes_ownership(s);  // ownership of the string data moves into the function
10        // println!("{}", s); // This would result in a compile-time error: use of a moved 
11                              // moved value: 's' 
12                                  
13    } // Variable S is dropped after main() execution                             
14             
15    fn takes_copy(num:i32) {
16        println!("Copied num: {}", num); 
17    } // num goes out of scope and is dropped here     
18               
19    fn takes_ownership(some_string:String) {
20        println!("{}", some_string);
21    }  // some_string goes out of scope and is dropped here  
22
  4. Borrowing allows temporary access without transferring ownership: Instead of moving ownership, one can simply borrow data of a variable using the reference operator.
    • Immutable reference (&T): Allow for the data to be read. There can be as many references as one desires simultaneously. 
      1     let s:String = String::from("Terrence Popp is a good man!"); 
2     let r1:&String = &s;  
3     let r2:&String = &s; // Multiple immutable borrows are fine
4     println!("{} {}.", r1, r2);               
5
    • Mutable reference (&mut T): Allow for the data to be read and modified. There can only be one mutable reference to a value at any given time, and so, there cannot be an immutable references that can coexist with it. It is either a single mutable reference or single/multiple immutable references, never both. 
      1     let mut s:String = String::from("Hello"); 
2     let r:&mut String = &mut s;  
3     r.push_str(" Dave!");
4     // Cannot create another reference while 'r' is active               
5

The following example program demonstrates when there can only be a single mutable reference to a value. A string variable s is initiated with "Hello".into(), then is printed to console. A String data type is a mutable, growable, heap-allocated collection in Rust. To demonstrate this mutability two push_str() were applied to s: the resulting string was "Hello Dave! You are awesome!".
A mutable reference was made of s and used to initiate r. A push_str(" Have a nice day!") was applied to variable r. The variable s was then print to console; the result was Hello Dave! You are awesome! Have a nice day!. The Rust statement push_str(" Have a nice day!") modified the value owned by variable s, this demonstrates that the mutable reference variable only contains the pointer (e.g. memory address) of the value and not the value itself.

In[54]:
fn refer_thing() {
    let mut s:String = "Hello".into();
    println!("String s: {}", s);
    
    s.push_str(" Dave!");
    println!("String s: {}", s);
    
    s.push_str(" You are awesome!");
    println!("String s: {}", s);
    
    let r:&mut String = &mut s;
    println!("Mutable Reference: {}", r);
    
    r.push_str(" Have a nice day!"); // push_str() to r modifies the value of s
    println!("\nString s: {}", s);
}
refer_thing();

String s: Hello
String s: Hello Dave!
String s: Hello Dave! You are awesome!
Mutable Reference: Hello Dave! You are awesome!

String s: Hello Dave! You are awesome! Have a nice day!

Borrow checker rules enforces these invariants:

  • There can be either:
    • A single or multiple immutable reference (e.g. &T) simultaneously, or
    • exactly one mutable reference (e.g. &mut T).
  • Never both types of reference can exist at the same time.
  • All references must be valid for their entire lifespan - no dangling references can exist.
  • Borrowed data is tied to the scope that the data is located within: a reference cannot outlive the value it borrows and hence the scope that that value inhabits.

These rules elimate data races in single-threaded code and make safe concurrency possible in multithreaded code (e.g., with Send and Sync traits).
On page 53, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author demonstrates the use of the reference operator & to initiate a reference variable r. The data type of the reference variable r is &i32; this will become an important note soon. The reference variable r is summed to the referenced variable a and assigned to a new variable b with data type i32. An issue arises with this summation, the variables a and r involves two different data types &i32 and i32 and two different data types cannot be summed. To resolve this issue of different data types, the deference operator * can be applied to variable r to deference it.

In[66]:
// Listing 2.10: Creating a reference

fn reference_thing() {
    let a:i32 = 42;
    // r is a reference to a 
    let r:&i32 = &a;
    // Adds a to a (via dereferencing r) and assigns
    // it to b
    let b:i32 = a + *r;

    // Prints to console: "a + a = 84" 
    println!("a + a = {}", b);
}
reference_thing();

a + a = 84

Another example program that demonstrates the reference and deference operators is the following found on pages 53-54, Mcnamara (2021) [1]. The variable haystack is an array [i32;10], and it is used in a for loop to search for the needle. A comparison is used to discern equivalence between the variable of needle:i32 and the iterated elements of [i32;10] which is item:&i32. An issue arises, two different data types cannot be compared: &i32 compared to i32. To resolve this comparison issue, an dereference operator * is applied to item.

In[52]:
// Listing 2.11: Searching for an integer in an array of integers

// Note: 0o204 is 132, and therefore, there are no hits
fn reference_thing2() {
    let needle:i32 = 0o204; // needle = 132
    let haystack:[i32;10] = [1, 1, 2, 5, 15, 52, 203, 877, 4140, 21147];

    // Iterates over references to elements within haystack
    for item in &haystack {
        // The syntax *item returns the item's referent
        if *item == needle {
            println!("{}: hit!", *item);
        }
    }
}
reference_thing2();

When Single Ownership is not Enough: Some data structures naturally require multiple owners (e.g., graph nodes with parent/child pointer, shared configuration). Rust provides interior mutability and reference counting for these specific cases:

  • Rc<T> (Reference Counted): For a single-threaded shared ownership. Increment a count on clone, drops when count reaches zero.
  • Arc<T> (Atomic Reference Counted): Thread-safe version of Rc<T> for concurrent use.
  • Interior mutability patterns like RefCall<T> (runtime borrow checking) or Mutex<T>/RwLock<T> (for thread-safe mutability).

Summary: Rust ownership system shifts the burden of memory management from runtime (GC (Garbage Collector) or manual malloc/free by user) to compile time. By tracking ownership, moves, and borrows through the data type system and borrow checker, Rust provides the safety of high-level programming languages with the performance and control of a system programming language, with benefits from zero-cost abstractions and runtime overhead. This is why Rust is a safe and fast programming language.

2.7 Project: Rending the Mandelbrot set

On pages 54-56, Mcnamara (2021) [1] the author provide an example program that finds and print a Mandelbrot set for parameters (1000, -2.0, 1.0, -1.0, 1.0, 100, 24). It is a neat Rust program.

In[59]:
// Listing 2.12 Rendering the Mandelbrot set

:dep num = {version = "0.4.3"}
extern crate num;
use num::complex::Complex;    // <1>: Imports the Complex number type from num crate and its complex submodule
                              
fn calculate_mandelbrot(      // <2>: Converts between the output space (a grid of rows and columns) and 
                              //      a range that surronds the Mandelbrot set (a continuous region near (0,0))
                              
  max_iters: usize,           // <3>: If a value has not escaped before reaching the maximum number of iterations,
  x_min: f64,                 //      it's considered to be within the Mandelbrot set.
  x_max: f64,                 // <4>: Parameters that specify the space we're searching for to look for members
  y_min: f64,                 //      of the set
  y_max: f64,                       
  width: usize,               // <5>: Parameters that represents the size of the output in pixels
  height: usize,              // 
  ) -> Vec<Vec<usize>> {

  let mut rows:Vec<_> = Vec::with_capacity(width); // <6>: Creates a container to house the data from each row
  for img_y in 0..height {                          // <7>: Iterates row by row, allowing us to print the output
                                                    //      line by line
    let mut row:Vec<usize> = Vec::with_capacity(height);
    for img_x in 0..width {

      let x_percent = (img_x as f64 / width as f64);
      let y_percent = (img_y as f64 / height as f64);
      let cx = x_min + (x_max - x_min) * x_percent; // <8>: Calculates the proportion of the space covered in our output 
      let cy = y_min + (y_max - y_min) * y_percent; //      and converts that to points within the search space
      let escaped_at = mandelbrot_at_point(cx, cy, max_iters);
      row.push(escaped_at);
    }

    rows.push(row);
  }
  rows
}

fn mandelbrot_at_point(   // <9>: Called at every pixel (e.g., every row and column that's
  cx: f64,                //      printed to stdout
  cy: f64,
  max_iters: usize,
  ) -> usize {
  let mut z = Complex { re: 0.0, im: 0.0 };       // <10>: Initializes a complex number at the origin with real (re)
                                                  //       and imaginary (im) parts at 0.0
  let c = Complex::new(cx, cy);                   // <11>: Initializes complex number from the coordinate provided 
                                                  //       as function arguments
  for i in 0..=max_iters {
    if z.norm() > 2.0 {                           // <12>: Checks the escape condition and calculates the distance from the 
      return i;                                   //       origin (0,0), an absolute value of a complex number
    }
    z = z * z + c;                                // <13>: Repeatedly mutates z to check whether c lies within the 
  }                                               //       Mandelbrot set.
  max_iters                                       // <14>: As i is no longer in scope, we fall back to max_iters
}

fn render_mandelbrot(escape_vals: Vec<Vec<usize>>) {
  for row in escape_vals {
    let mut line = String::with_capacity(row.len());
    for column in row {
      let val = match column {
        0..=2 => ' ',
        3..=5 => '.',
        6..=10 => '',
        11..=30 => '*',
        31..=100 => '+',
        101..=200 => 'x',
        201..=400 => '$',
        401..=700 => '#',
        _ => '%',
      };

      line.push(val);
    }
    println!("{}", line);
  }
}

fn main() {
  
  let mandelbrot = calculate_mandelbrot(1000, -2.0, 1.0, -1.0,
                                        1.0, 100, 24);

  render_mandelbrot(mandelbrot);
}
main();

     ....................................**%%$*%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%*+*+x***..............    
    ..................................****$%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%*...............   
   ....................**+%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%*...............  
  ...................****+***%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%**...............

2.8 Advanced function definitons

Definition: The lifetimes system in Rust is a compile-time mechanism that tracks the scope (or region of code) of which a reference/borrow is valid within. This system ensures that a reference can never outlive the data that which it was borrowed from, preventing the possibility of the reference becoming a dangling reference after cleanup.
Together the Rust's ownership and borrowing, and lifetimes systems eliminate the need for a garbage collector (GC). The borrow checker statically verifies - at compile time - that all borrowing rules were followed and references remained valid throughout the program. This restrict system provides the same safety benefits that are afforded to higher-level programming languages that implement a GC, without the need for a GC and its associated overheads.

Concise Context: What Constitutes Runtime Overheard in Garbage-Collected Programming Languages? The typically Runtime overheads that are found in GC-based programming languages (e.g., Java, Go, Python, JavaScript):

  • Periodic GC pasues: The executing program halts (or partially halts) while the GC scans for unreachable objects and free memory. These "stop-the-world" or concurrent pauses are what can cause latency spikes with a program execution, unpredictable variability in performance, and jitters - critical issues in real-time systems, video games, or embedded system environments.
  • Memory scanning and bookkeeping: The CG during runtime maintains extra metadata (e.g., reference counts, mark bits, generational heaps, et cetera) and tracks through execution the reachability and thus validity of object within the program. All of this requires additional overhead.
  • Allocation overhead: Heap allocation maybe faster initially, but fragmentation and CG's garbage collection cycles add indirect costs.
  • Increased memory usage: GC's oftentimes retain objects longer than necessary to reduce the need for and frequency of garbage collection cycles during program execution.

In contrast, Rust's strict ownership, borrowing and lifetimes systems, all enforce strict memory safety measures entirely at compile time. Once a Rust program compiles, there exists no additional overhead cost for memory management. Resources are freed/dropped from the program predictably via deterministic Drop calls exactly scopes end, which provides the same computational performance of a C++ program with far greater memory safety.
On pages 56-58, Mcnamara (2021) [1], lifetimes system within Rust is introduced through an snippet example program.

In[63]:
// Listing 2.13: A function signature with explicit lifetime annotations

fn add_with_lifetime<'a, 'b>(i: &'a i32, j: &'b i32) -> i32 {
    return *i + *j;
}

The full example program is provided by the author on page 57, Mcnamara (2021) [1], alongside a list of useful explanations.

  • fn add_with_lifetime(...) -> i32 should be familiar to you already. From this we can infer that add_with_lifetime() is a [standard] function that returns a i32.
  • <'a, b'> declares two lifetime variables, 'a and 'b, within the scope of add_with_lifetimes(). These are normally spoken as lifetime a and lifetime b.
  • i: &'a i32 bind lifetime variable 'a to lifetime of i. The syntax reads as "parameter i is a reference to an i32 with lifetime a."
  • j: &'b i32 binds the lifetime variable 'b to the lifetime of j. The syntax reads as "parameter j is a reference to an i32 with lifetime b."

Sometimes the Rust compiler requires additional user context regarding variable lifetimes, as it might not be able to inference the lifetime of a variable - without assistance. This could occur in such a case where a function accepts multiple references as arguments or returns a reference as its returning data type. The Rust compiler will prompt the programmer through error message to provide additional context information in the form of explicit lifetime annotation, when compiler itself cannot discern the lifetime of a variable.

In[71]:
// Listing 2.14: Data type signature of a function with lifetime explicit annotations

fn add_with_lifetimes<'a, 'b>(i: &'a i32, j: &'b i32) -> i32 {
    return *i + *j;  // Adds the values referred to by i and j than adding
}                    // the references directly

fn main() {
    let a:i32 = 10;
    let b:i32 = 20;
    let res:i32 = add_with_lifetimes(&a, &b);  // &10 and &20 mean reference 10 and 20, respectively.
                                               // No lifetime notation is required when calling 
    println!("{}", res);                       // a function.
}
main();

30

On page 58, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the example demonstrate an unconstrained generic function, and it shows that the unconstrainted generic function results in a compiler error message. The reason for the error message is that the generic data type T represents any data type, and that includes data types that do not support the addition operator +. The Rust compiler cannot infer the data type T supports the addition operator + or any other trait. The compiler requireds the programmer to specify a trait constraint, so that it can narrow down the possible data types that T can represent. In case of the add() function, the std::ops::Add trait is needed to constrain T; limiting the data types that T can represent to thoses that implemented the addition operator +.
From page 59, On page 58, Mcnamara (2021) [1]: In Rust, a trait defines shared behavior (e.g. methods) that a data type can implement, which is similar to an interface, enabling polymorphism by specifying a contract/constraint/trait bound for functionality of a generic function in regard to what traits are implemented, such as the addition operator + or other operators, or methods. In Rust, operators are defined by traits.

In[73]:
// Listing 2.15: Data Type signature of a generic function

fn add<T>(i: T, j: T) -> T {  // The data type variable T is introduced with angle brackets (e.g. <T>).
    return i + j;             // This function takes two arguments of the same data type and returns a
}                             // value of that data type.

 3  fn add<T>(i: T, j: T) -> T {  // The data type variable T is introduced with angle brackets (e.g. <T>).

In Rust, generic functions are functions that are parameteerized by one or more data type parameters, allowing these functions to operate on multiple data types while maintaining data type safety and reusability. A generic function is defined by the placement of the generic data type within angle brackets <T> as a suffix of the function identifier and a prefix of the parameter list (). The following example demonstrate a generic function that accepts a referenced generic data typed array &[T] and returns a referenced generic type T.

In[16]:
fn example_largest_number() {
    let num_list1:[i32;12] = [20, 17, 9, 4, 5, 72, 35, 86, 78, 96, 31, 43];
    let num_list2:[f64;12] = [25.0, 14.0, 83.0, 54.0, 32.0, 92.0, 80.0, 42.0, 67.0, 89.0, 45.0, 52.0];

    println!("Largest number of num_list1: {}", largest(&num_list1));
    println!("Largest number of num_list2: {:.2}", largest(&num_list2));
}

fn largest<T: std::cmp::PartialOrd>(list: &[T]) -> &T {
    let mut largest_num = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest_num {
            largest_num = item;
        }
    }
    return largest_num;
}

example_largest_number();

Largest number of num_list1: 96
Largest number of num_list2: 92.00

Here, the generic data type T is constrained by the PartialOrd trait - which enable the comparison of value of the data type T within this function. The Rust compiler inters a concrete data type when the function is called; e.g. largest::<i32>(&vec).
During compile time the Rust compiler performs monomorphization on the generic function, to generate specialized versions of the function for each concrete data type used, ensuring that zero runtime overhead would be incurred during execution compared to the non-generic code. Generic functions enable flexibility and reusability within code and are commonly found within the standard library (e.g., Vec<T>, Option<T>).
The following example can be found on page 58, Mcnamara (2021) [1]. This generic function demonstrates how to constrain data type parameters with trait bound using the std::ops::Add trait:

In[29]:
// Listing 2.16: Data Type signature of a generic function with trait bounds

fn add<T: std::ops::Add<Output = T>>(i: T, j: T) -> T {
    return i + j;
}
  • <T: std::ops::Add<Output = T>> declares a generic data type T that must implement the Add trait, where the output of the addition (e.g. Output) is the same data type T itslef - which ensures the result of i + j is also data type T.
  • This allows the addition operator + to be used safely within the function body.
  • The function works for any data type that implements the Add trait, such as, primative data types i32, f64, et cetera, and user-defined data types that implement the Add trait.
In[31]:
// Rust Jupyter Notebook allows this type of execution of Rust code
println!("5 + 3 = {}", add(5,3)); // data types are i32
println!("2.5 + 1.5 = {:.2}", add(2.5, 1.5)); // data types are f64

5 + 3 = 8
2.5 + 1.5 = 4.00

This pattern is idiomatic in Rust: it provides the flexibility of generics while guaranteeing - at compile time that the required operations - such as the addition operator + - are available and type-correct.
On page 60, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author provide us readers with an example that demonstrates that generic functions can accept different data types as arguments, so long as they implement the need trait for the generic function to be functional. In case of Listing 2.16, the generic function accepts data types that implement the Add trait.

In[4]:
// Listing 2.17: A generic function with a data type variable and trait bounds

use std::ops::{ Add };
use std::time::{ Duration };

fn add<T: Add<Output = T>>(i: T, j: T) -> T {
    return i + j;
}

fn main() {
    let floats = add(1.2, 3.4);
    let ints = add(10, 20);
    let durations = add(Duration::new(5, 0), Duration::new(10, 0));

    println!("floats: {}", floats);
    println!("ints: {}", ints);
    println!("durations: {:?}", durations);
}
main();

floats: 4.6
ints: 30
durations: 15s

A generic function can be defined to accept multiple different data types as agruments; for readability the where clause can be used to define the bound traits for each generic argument. Multiple bound traits can be implemented by the use of the +, e.g. bound trait + bound trait + ....

In[109]:
fn mix_and_add<T, U>(a: T, b: U) -> T::Output 
where
    T: std::ops::Add<U>, // T can be added to U
{
    return a + b;
}

fn main() {
    let s1:String = String::from("Bob the builder, ");
    let s2:&str = "can we fix it?";

    let s3:String = mix_and_add(s1, s2);
    println!("Combined String: {}", s3);
}
main();

Combined String: Bob the builder, can we fix it?

On page 60, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author provide a few principles that will assist programmer in reading Rust code.

  • Term in lowercase (i, j) denote variables.
  • Single uppercase letters (e.g. T) denote generic type variables.
  • Term beginning with uppercase (e.g. Add) are either traits or concrete data types, such as String or Duration.
  • Labels (e.g. 'a) denote lifetime parameters.

2.9 Creating Grep-lite

The example is from page 60 of Mcnamara (2021) [1], and it demonstrate several features of the Rust programming language. A string literal is an immutable representation of UTF-8 characters. In the example a paragraph is stored within a string literal and assigned to a variable quote. This demonstrates that a string literal variable can be defined over multiple coding lines and that it is versatile enough to store large quantity of text data.
Since this example is being coded within a Rust Jupyter Notebook, a problem arose where the escape backslash was causing a compile error. To remove the newline character, the variable quote was initiated as a variable String, then the trim_start() method was applied to it. Since trim_start() returns a string literal &str, the to_string() method was applied to turn the &str into a String.
In the example the author uses a for loop and lines() to iterate over quote line-by-line. The contains method was used to discern if the iterated line contained search_term:&str = "picture". The result is that the second line is printed to console: "dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?".
I modified the code further to include an index in the iteration over quote. Since lines() return an iterator, the enumerate methods can be applied to it to generate an index.

In[26]:
// Listing 2.18: Searching for a search simple pattern within lines of a string

fn main() {
    let search_term:&str = "picture";
    let mut quote:String = "                                                       
    Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and
    dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
    It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?".to_string(); // <1>: Multilined string do not require special 
                                                                                        // syntax. The \ character on line excapes 
                                                                                        // the new line character. (Does not work in a
    // Remove newline character at the start                                            // Rust Jupyter Notebook)
    quote = quote.trim_start().to_string();
    
    for (index, line) in quote.lines().enumerate() {                        // <2>: Lines() returns an iterator over quote where each
        if line.contains(search_term) {                                     // iteration is a line of text. Rust uses each operating system's
            println!("Line Number {}: {}", index, line);                    // conventions on what constitutes a new line.
        }
    }
    
}
main();

Line Number 1:     dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?

To retain a similarity to the author's implementation on pages 60-61 of Mcnamara (2021) [1], the newline character can be trimmed by trim_start() method, which returns a &str. The rest of the author's code remained unchanged after this minor modification, as the trimmed quotation of text is returned as a &str, the variable quote can be initialized as a &str.

    let mut quote:&str = "                                                       
    Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and
    dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
    It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?".trim_start(); // <1>: Multilined string do not require special 
                                                                                         // syntax. The \ character on line excapes 
                                                                                         // the new line character. (Does not work in a
                                                                                         // Rust Jupyter Notebook).
    
    for line in quote.lines() {                        // <2>: Lines() returns an iterator over quote where each
        if line.contains(search_term) {                                     // iteration is a line of text. Rust uses each operating system's
            println!("{}", line);                    // conventions on what constitutes a new line.
        }
    }
    
}

The example Listing 2.19 provided by the author on page 63 of Mcnamara (2021) [1] extrapolates on Listing 2.18 by introducing an line count to account for which line of the quote is printed to console. A variable named line_num is initiated to track the line number during the iteration of quote. After each iteration line_num is incremented by 1.

In[42]:
// 2.19: Manually incrementing an index variable

fn main() {
    let search_term:&str = "picture";
    let mut quote:String = "Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and
    dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
    It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?".into(); // <1>: A backslash escapes the newline character 
                                                                                   // in the string literal

    quote = quote.trim_start().to_string();

    let mut line_num:usize = 1; // <2>: Declear line_num as mutable via let mut and initialize it with 1

    for line in quote.lines() {
        if line.contains(search_term) {
            println!("Line {}: {}", line_num, line.trim_start()); // trim_start to remove newline character
        }
        line_num += 1;
    }
}
main();

Line 2: dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?

In further extrapolating the example from Listing 2.19 in Listing 2.20, the author introduces the enumerate() method. The enumerate() method accepts an iterator and returns an iterator that contains a count and the element of the accepted iterator. With an enternal count tracking the line number, the variable num_line can be summed with this count to keep track of the current line being iterated from quote. Subsequently the line number and the line can be print to console simultaneously.

In[16]:
// Listing 2.20: Automatically incrementing an index variable

fn main() {
    let search_term:&str = "picture";
    let mut quote:String = "Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and
    dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
    It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?".into(); // <1>: A backslash escapes the newline character 
                                                                                   // in the string literal

    quote = quote.trim_start().to_string();

    let mut line_num:usize = 1; // <2>: Declares line_num as mutable via let mut and initialize it with 1

    // 1 based index for accounting for line
    for (index, line) in quote.lines().enumerate() {               // <3>: Because lines() returns as iterator, it can be chained 
        if line.contains(search_term) {                            // with enumerate()
            line_num = index + 1;
            println!("Line {}: {}", line_num, line.trim_start()); // trim_start() to remove starting newline character
        }
    }

    println!(" ");

    // 0 based index for account for line
    for (index, line) in quote.lines().enumerate() {
        println!("Line {}: {}", index, line.trim_start()); // trim_start() to remove starting newline character
    }

}
main();

Line 2: dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
 
Line 0: Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and
Line 1: dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
Line 2: It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?

2.10 Making lists of Things with arrays, slices, and vectors

Array [T; N]: An array in Rust is a fixed collection of elements of the same data type T, with a length of N, both of which are known by the compiler at compile time. A Rust array is stored on the stack memory, and has a fixed memory cost due associated with it due to its immutable nature. Its element can be accessed by index in O(1).

In[45]:
fn main() {
    let mut fruits:[&str; 4] = ["apple", "orange", "banana", "coconut"];
    println!("fruits: {:?}\n", fruits);

    // access an element of an array
    println!("Index 1: {}\n", fruits[1]);
    // accessing multiple elements of an array - generates a slice
    println!("Index 1-3: {:?}\n", &fruits[1..3]);
    // reverse the order of an array's elements
    let reversed:Vec<&&str> = fruits.iter().rev().collect();
    println!("Revered order of fruits: {:?}\n", reversed);

    // iterate over an array
    for fruit in &fruits {
        println!("{}", fruit);
    }

    // print the length of an array
    println!("\nLength of array: {}\n", fruits.len());
    // return bollean; checks if an element is within an array
    println!("Result for apple: {}", fruits.contains(&"apple")); // checks if string literal is an element
    println!("Result for fits: {}", fruits.contains(&"fits"));
    
}
main();

fruits: ["apple", "orange", "banana", "coconut"]

Index 1: orange

Index 1-3: ["orange", "banana"]

Revered order of fruits: ["coconut", "banana", "orange", "apple"]

orange
banana
coconut

Length of array: 4

Result for apple: true
Result for fits: false

On pages 64-65, Mcnamara (2021) [1], concisely describes arrays in Rust, in other words [T; N], and demonstrates their functionality within the programming language. In Listing 2.21 the author demonstrates how an array can be generated using a variety of different syntaxes, and how an array can be iterated over with a for loop. Although it should be noted that the idiomatic approach to iterate over a collection with a for loop is for index_element in collection { \\ code }. This approach prevents the possibility of an out of bounds index occurring when the for loop iterates over a collection.

In[41]:
// 2.21: Defining arrays and iterating over their elements

fn main() {
    let one = [1, 2, 3];
    let two:[u8;3] = [1, 2, 3];
    let blank1 = [0; 3];
    let blank2:[u8;3] = [0; 3];
    let mut sum:u8 = 0;

    let arrays:[[u8;3];4] = [one, two, blank1, blank2]; // An array of arrays - the length of each array
                                                    // must be of equal length

    for a in &arrays {
        print!("{:?}: ", a);
        for n in a.iter() {
            print!("\t{} + 10 = {}", n, n+10);
        }
        
        for m in 0..a.len() {
            sum += a[m];
        }
        println!("\t({:?} = {})", a, sum);
    }

}
main();

[1, 2, 3]: 	1 + 10 = 11	2 + 10 = 12	3 + 10 = 13	([1, 2, 3] = 6)
[1, 2, 3]: 	1 + 10 = 11	2 + 10 = 12	3 + 10 = 13	([1, 2, 3] = 12)
[0, 0, 0]: 	0 + 10 = 10	0 + 10 = 10	0 + 10 = 10	([0, 0, 0] = 12)
[0, 0, 0]: 	0 + 10 = 10	0 + 10 = 10	0 + 10 = 10	([0, 0, 0] = 12)

Slice &[T] or &mut [T]: In Rust, a slice is a reference to a contiguous sequence of elements in a collection, such as, an array, vector or String, ownership of the contiguous sequence of elements is not transferred to the slice.

1     // General slice                String slice (most frequent special case)      
2     &[T]                            &str
3     &mut [T]                        &mut str   // (rare)
4

The following example program demonstrates the various slice syntaxes used for [T;N] Vec<T> and String.

In[64]:
fn main() {
    let numbers:[i32;5] = [10, 20, 30, 40, 50];

    // Various slice syntaxes (all create &i32 slices)
    let full:&[i32] = &numbers[..];
    println!("full: {:?}", full);
    let part:&[i32] = &numbers[1..4];
    println!("part: {:?}", part);
    let from_2:&[i32] = &numbers[2..];
    println!("from_2: {:?}", from_2);
    let until_3:&[i32] = &numbers[..3];
    println!("until_3: {:?}", until_3);
    let one:&[i32] = &numbers[0..1];
    println!("Just first element: {:?}", one);

    let word:Vec<&str> = Vec::from(["a", "w", "e", "s", "o", "m", "e"]);

    // Slice syntax same for vec
    println!("\npartial: {:?}", &word[0..4]);

    // String slice is very common
    let s:String = String::from("   ||   by arishanya");
    println!("\nfull string: {}", s);
    let first_half:&str = &s[0..s.len()/2];
    println!("first half: {}", first_half);
    let second_half:&str = &s[s.len()/2..];
    println!("second half: {}", second_half);
}
main();

full: [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]
part: [20, 30, 40]
from_2: [30, 40, 50]
until_3: [10, 20, 30]
Just first element: [10]

partial: ["a", "w", "e", "s"]

full string:    ||   by arishanya
first half:    
second half: ||   by arishanya

Key points in one sentence: A slice is a fat pointer (e.g., ptr + length) that gives you a view into existing data - it never owns or copies the underlying elements.

Vector Vec<T>: A vector in Rust is a growable, heap-allocated array-like collection, its elements are the same data type T. A vector can dynamically resize (e.g., push/pop elements), remain ordered, and provide index access to its elements. It is conventionally the standard mutable and dynamic list in the Rust programming language.

In[45]:
fn main() {
    // generates Vec<&str>
    let fruits1:Vec<&str> = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry", "strawberry"];
    // generates Vec<String>
    let fruits2:Vec<String> = vec!["apple".to_string(), "banana".to_string(), "cherry".to_string(), "strawberry".to_string()];
    // generates a mutable empty Vec<&str> 
    let mut vegetables:Vec<&str> = Vec::<&str>::new();
    println!("Vegetables: {:?}", vegetables);

    // Add an element to vegetables
    vegetables.push("cabbage");
    println!("Vegetables: {:?}", vegetables);
    // Like Python, an existing element can be replaced
    vegetables[0] = "peas"; 
    println!("vegetables: {:?}\n", vegetables);

    // generates a mutable empty Vec<String>
    let mut vegetables2:Vec<String> = vec![];
    println!("vegetables2: {:?}", vegetables2);
    vegetables2.push("tomato".to_string());
    vegetables2.push("carrots".to_string());
    vegetables2.push("broccoli".to_string());
    println!("vegetables2: {:?}", vegetables2);
    vegetables2[1] = String::from("potato");
    vegetables2[2] = String::from("onion");
    println!("vegetables2: {:?}", vegetables2);

    // replace an element safely
    vegetables2.push("zucchine".to_string());
    println!("vegetables2: {:?} \n(Note: I don't like zucchinis.)", vegetables2);

    let length:usize = vegetables2.len();
    if let Some(vege) = vegetables2.get_mut(length-1) {
        *vege = String::from("beans");
    }
    println!("vegetables2: {:?} \n(Note: That is better.)", vegetables2);

    // This is also a viable solution to replace the zucchini element from vegetables2
    // if let Some(last) = vegetables2.last_mut() {
    //     *last = String::from("beans");
    // }

    // Vector operations
    let a:Vec<&str> = vec!["a", "b"];
    let b:Vec<&str> = vec!["c", "d"];
    println!("\nvector a: {:?}\nvector b: {:?}\n", a, b);

    // Add (concatenate) two vectors - creates a new vector
    let concatenated:Vec<&&str> = a.iter().chain(b.iter()).clone().collect();
    println!("Concatenated vectors a and b: {:?}\n", concatenated);
    // Alternative approach to add (concatenate) two vectors
    let concatenated2:Vec<&str> = [a, b.clone()].concat();
    println!("Concatenated vectors a and b: {:?}\n", concatenated2);

    // To modify in place: extend one vector with another vector
    let mut c:Vec<&str> = vec!["a", "b"];
    println!("Vector c: {:?}", c);
    c.extend(&b);
    println!("Extended vector c: {:?}\n", c);

    // Append an element to a vector
    c.push("e");
    println!("New vector c (appended): {:?}", c); 

    // Remove the last element (pop)                                             
    c.pop();                                                               
    println!("New vector c (popped): {:?}", c);                                   
    c.pop();                                                                     
    println!("New vector c (popped): {:?}", c);                               
                                                                             
    // Insert an element at a given index                                 
    c.insert(2,"d");                                                     
    println!("New vector c (insertion): {:?}", c);                              
                                                                                 
    // Reverse the order of a vector                                        
    c.reverse();                                                                  
    println!("New vector c (reversed order): {:?}", c);                         
                                                                            
    // Sort elements alphabetically                                       
    c.sort();                                                                      
    println!("New vector c (sorted): {:?}", c);                                    
                                                                        
    // Reverse alphabetical order                                            
    c.sort_by(|x, y| y.cmp(x));                                         // or a.sort(); a.reverse();
    println!("New vector c (reversed alphabetical): {:?}\n", c);

    // Return the index of the first occurrence of a given value
    if let Some(idx) = c.iter().position(|&x| x == "c") {
        println!("Position of 'c' is index {}.\n", idx);
    }

    // Counts the number of occurrences of a given value
    c.push("a");
    println!("'a' occurred: {} times", c.iter().filter(|&&x| x == "a").count());
    println!("'f' occured: {} times\n", c.iter().filter(|&&x| x == "f").count());

    // Clear a vector (removes all elements, but keeps memory capacity allocated to it)
    c.clear();
    println!("New vector c (cleared): {:?}", c);
}
main();

On pages 66-67, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author uses a more elaborate example (e.g. that of Listing 2.22) to demonstrate the functionality of vectors (e.g. Vec). Within Listing 2.22 a vector named tags is used to store the line indexes where the string "oo" is found within. The result is tags:Vec = [1,6], where line 2 and 7 can words with "oo". Another vector ctx was used to store the text data and line numbers assocaited with each line; the Vec> collection was subsequently used to print the text content and their associate line index to the console.

In[62]:
// 2.22: Enabling context lines to be printed out with a Vec<Vec<T>>
fn main() {
    let ctx_lines = 2;
    let needle:&str = "oo";
    let haystack:&str = "
    Every face, every shop,
    bedroom window, public-home, and
    dark square is a picture
    feverishly turned--in search of what?
    dark square is a picture
    feverishly turned--in search of what?
    It is the same with books.
    What do we seek
    through millions of pages?".trim_start();

    let mut tags:Vec<usize> = vec![];                // <1>: tags holds line numbers where matches occur.
    let mut ctx:Vec<Vec<(usize, String)>> = vec![];  // <2>: ctx contains a vector per match to hold the context line.

    // <3>: Iterates through the lines, recording line numbers where matches are encountered
    for (index, line) in haystack.lines().enumerate() {
        if line.contains(needle) {
            println!("Line {}: {}", index+1, line.trim_start());
            tags.push(index);

            // <4>: Vec::with_capacity(n) reserves space for n items. No explicit type signature 
            // is required as it can be inferred via the definition of ctx on lines 14-15
            let v = Vec::with_capacity(2*ctx_lines + 1);
            ctx.push(v);
        }
    }

    println!("\ntags: {:?}", tags);
    println!("ctx: {:?}\n", ctx);

    // <5>: When there are no matches, exit early
    if tags.is_empty() {
        return;
    }

    for (index, line) in haystack.lines().enumerate() {      // <6>: For each tag, at every line, checks to see if we are near a match. 
        for (j_index, tag) in tags.iter().enumerate() {      // When we are, add that line to the relevant Vec<T> within ctx
            let lower_bound = tag.saturating_sub(ctx_lines); // <7>: saturating_sub() is subtraction that returns 0 on integers that underflow
            let upper_bound = tag + ctx_lines;               // rather than crashing the program (CPUs don't like attempting to send usize
                                                             // below zero).
            if (index >= lower_bound) && (index <= upper_bound) {
                let line_as_string:String = String::from(line.trim_start());  // <8>: Copies the line into a new string and stores that
                let local_ctx:(usize, String) = (index, line_as_string);      // locally for each match
                ctx[j_index].push(local_ctx);
            }
        }
    }

    println!("\ntags: {:?}", tags);
    println!("ctx: {:?}\n", ctx);

    for local_ctx in ctx.iter() {
        for &(i, ref line) in local_ctx.iter() {      // <9>: ref line informs the compiler that we want to borrow this value
            let line_num = i + 1;                     // rather than move it. These two terms are explained fully in
            println!("Line {}: {}", line_num, line);  // later chapters
        }
    }
}
main();

Line 7: It is the same with books.

On page 67, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author explains that a vector can be generated with a specifically memory allocated size using with_capacity(), which has the benefit of reducing runtime overhead while the program executes. The following example demonstrate the functionality of with_capacity().

In[75]:
fn main() {
    let mut vector:Vec<&str> = Vec::with_capacity(3);
    let mut count:usize = 1;

    vector.push("Halo 3");
    vector.push("GTA IV");
    vector.push("Half-Life 2: Episode 2");
    
    for i in vector {
        println!("Count {}: {}", count, i);
        count += 1;
    }
}
main();

2.11 Including third-party code

A crate in Rust is the fundamental unit of code compilation, distribution, and reuse. A concise definition is as follows:

    A crate is a compilation unit in the Rust programming language, it is either:
  • a library crate - which produces a .rlib file, of which can be used by other crates,
  • or is a binary crate - that produces an executable program.
    Every Rust project has exactly one crate root file:
  • scr/lib.rs library crate
  • scr/main.rs binary crate
  • scr/bin/*.rs additional binary crates (optional)

A crate is a Rust package - that includes its own Cargo.toml file - that compiles into either a library that other crates can depend upon or into a standalone executable program.
Recall that the Cargo.toml file was briefly mentioned in Section 1.3 of Mcnamara (2021) [1], and that this file is what contained the Rust's project name, version, author and dependencies. The toml file is written in the TOML (Tom's Obvious Minimal Language) format. The [package] section within the Cargo.toml file is the primary metadata block that describes the identity of the Rust project. The name field described the name of the Rust project or crate and is a required field to have defined within a TOML file.

[package]
name = "my_awesome_project/crate"     # This is how to make comments within a TOML file
version = "0.2.1"
edition = "2021"
authors = ["You <you@example_email.com>"]
description = "Does something of use."
license = "MIT or Apache-2.0"
    Key points about the relationship between package, Cargo.toml, and crate name.
  • A Rust package contains a Cargo.toml and the source code that it describes.
  • A Rust crate almost always produces one primary crate whose name comes directly from [package] name = "...".
    • When other developers write extern crate my_awesome_crate or use my_awesome_crate that are using the name of the crated described in [package] name = "..." of the package section of the TOML file.
    • When a developer publishes their crate to crates.io, the routing address will include the project name, e.g., http://crates.io/crates/my_awesome_crate.
  • The same Rust package can produce multiple crates at once:
    • at most the Rust package contains one library crate - usually from scr/main.rs name = [package] name = "..." - unless overridden in [[lib]].
    • a Rust package can contain zero or more binary crates from scr/main.rs and/or src/bin/*.rs; conventionally each of these binary crates receives the package name or a custin name via [[bin]].
  • Cargo.toml is written in the TOML (Tom's Obvious Minimal Language) format and typically contains:
    • project name and version
    • authors, project description, licenses and licensing, and repository
    • project dependencies [dependencies], [dev-dependencies], [build-dependencies] (e.g. what external excrates that the Rust project uses and needs.)
    • optional sections such as [features], [workspace], [lib], [[bin]], et cetera.

Listing 2.23 of page 68, Mcnamara (2021) [1], demonstrates how a string literal can be iterated over line-by-line with the use of a for loop and qoute.lines(). The .lines() method uses needle: '\n' to split the string literal quote into separate string slices and stores these slices into haystack: "Every face, every shop, bedroom window, .... The following Debug print is of the iterator itself that is produced from qoute.lines().

What do we seek through millions of pages?", finger: 0, finger_back: 201, needle: '\n', utf8_size: 1, utf8_encoded: [10, 0, 0, 0] }, allow_trailing_empty: false, finished: false } } })

This iteraor is passed to a for loop and that for loop iterates over the elements found within haystack:. In case of Listing 2.23 the three lines of quote are printed to console (Note: We included the .enumerate() method to generate an index and thus provide a 0-based line number).

// Listing 2.23: Matching on exact strings with the contains() method

fn main() {
    let search_term:&str = "picture";
    let quote:&str = "Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-home, and 
    dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what? 
    It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?";

    for (index, line) in quote.lines().enumerate() {
        if line.contains(search_term) {
            println!("Line {}: {}", index, line);
        }
    }
}

Listing 2.24 of page 69, Mcnamara (2021) [1], demonstrate the Rust crate Regex in the use of pattern search within string literal captured text. The Regex crate provides methods to search String and &str captured text for matches with the use of a regular expression (e.g. abbreviated to regex by the crate authors) [11]. In case of Listing 2.24, the regular expression that is used is "oo". The regular expression is stored within a &str and passed into the main constructor Regex::new("oo"). The .find() method from impl Regex can be used to search within a string text for the regular expression "oo"; returns matching string text wrapped within an Option data type. The quote contained two lines with the searched for regular expression: lines 1 and 6.

In[109]:
// 2.24 Listing: Searching for patterns with regular expressions

:dep regex = {version = "1.12.2"}  
extern crate regex;                
use regex::Regex;                  // <1>: Brings the Regex data type from the regex crate
                                   // into local scope

fn main() {
    let re:Regex = Regex::new("oo").expect("Expected Regex wrapped string literal.");  // <2>: Regex struct returns a Result<Ok(), Err()>
                                                                                       // data type, and requiring an unwrapping method.
                                                                                       // Unlike the author choice, the .expect() unwraps
                                                                                       // when it receives Ok(), and returns panic! when
                                                                                       // it receives Err()
    let quote:&str = "
    Every face, every shop,
    bedroom window, public-home, and
    dark square is a picture
    feverishly turned--in search of what?
    dark square is a picture
    feverishly turned--in search of what?
    It is the same with books.
    What do we seek
    through millions of pages?".trim_start();

    for (index, line) in quote.lines().enumerate() {
        let contains_substring = re.find(line);    // <3>: Replaces the contains method from Listing 2.23 
        // println!("{:?}", contains_substring);   // with re.find(line) which is from the regex crate

        match contains_substring {                                               // <4>: returns an Option<Some(), NONE>, which needs
            Some(thing) => println!("Line {}: {:?}", index, line.trim_start()),  // to be unwrapped. A match statement performs this
            None => (),                                                          // unwrapping. But instead of wrapping, a match statement
        }                                                                        // used for pattern recognition: one pattern for one behavior
    }                                                                            // and one pattern for another behavior.

}
main();

Line 1: "bedroom window, public-home, and"
Line 6: "It is the same with books."

2.12 Supporting command-line arguments

Since the publication of Mcnamara (2021) [1] the Clap crated has been updated to include a different syntax then the one found within this textbook. To make the Listing example program functional again, the syntax of these examples had to be modified. To ported these example to the present-day the modern version of regex and clap were used to generate the following updated version of these examples.
On pages 71-72 of Mcnamara (2021) [1] the author introduces the Clap crate, which is a polished CLI (command-line interface) that allows a programmer the capacity to build their own built-in line-commands [12]. In the case of Listing 2.26 the line-commend is built to accept the desired search pattern within the command-line: e.g. following the cargo run command a suffix command -- oo is included for the desired search term "oo".

Listing 2.25: Adding a dependency to grep-lite/Cargo.toml

[package]
name = "grep-lite"   
version = "0.1.0"
authors = ["Tim McNamara <author@rustinaction.com>"]
description = "Does something of use."
license = "MIT or Apache-2.0"

[dependencies]
regex = "1.4.2"
clap = "4.5.54"
In[2]:
// Listing 2.26: Editing grep-lite/scr/main.rs

:dep regex = {version = "1.12.2"} 
:dep clap = { version = "4.5.54" }
extern crate regex;
extern crate clap;
use regex::Regex;
use clap::{ Command, Arg };  // <1>: Brings clap::Command and clap::Arg structs 
                         // into local scope

fn main() {
    let args = Command::new("grip=lite")        // <2>: Incrementally build a command argument parser,
        .version("0.1")                         // where each argument takes an Arg. In our case, we 
        .about("searches for patterns")         // only need one.c
        .arg(Arg::new("pattern")                
            .help("The pattern to search for")  // 
            .required(true)
            .value_name("pattern"))
        .get_matches();

    // <3>: Extract the pattern argument.
    let pattern = args.get_one::<String>("pattern").expect("A pattern is required.");  

    let re:Regex = match Regex::new(pattern) {
        Ok(result) => result,
        Err(e) => { 
            println!("Error: Regex data types couldn't be created.\nError Message: {}", e);
            return;
        },
    };

    let quote:&str = "Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and
    dark square is a picture feverishly turned -- in search of what?
    It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?";

    for (index, line) in quote.lines().enumerate() {
        match re.find(line) {
            Some(selected_line) => println!("Line {}: {}  {:?} ", index, line.trim(), selected_line.as_str()),
            None => (),
        }
    }
}

2.13 Reading from files

Reading a file in Rust means loading data from the file management system into your Rust program or Project (e.g. usually as either a text or bytes format). The following is the process of reading a file through standard library crate in Rust.

  1. Locate the file's path, e.g., "config.toml", "/var/log/app.log", image/logo.png.
  2. Open it with read permission.
  3. Transfer the bytes stored on disk (or SSD/NVMe/...) into your Rust program's memory.
  4. Program access bytes data - as raw UTF-8 decimal representation [u8], valid UTF-8 String and &str, line-by-line, et cetera.
Different for loop constructs and respective data access
Form Rust Data Type What it represents Most common method when... Convenience function
Raw bytes Vec<u8> Exact bytes from disk (any format). Images, Binaries, PDFs, compressed data, unknown encoding. fs::read(path)
Valid UTF-8 text String Human-readable text (most config formats) .toml, .json, .yaml, .env, source code, logs (e.g. UTF-8). fs::read_to_string(path)
Lines of text String (e.g. one by one) Line-by-line processing. Large logs, CSV, structured text files. BufReader::lines()
Chunk/custom formats Slices of [u8] Fine-grained or streaming control. Very large files, parsing protocols, zero-copy desires. Read::read()/.fill_buf()

The following are simple but most common examples where files are read into a Rust program. The first example demonstrates that a file can be read into a String data typed variable within a Rust program, and that the data within the file will be converted into a UTF-8 representation. For this example, a text file was created, its contents contains the full words of the "You Shall Know No Fear" speech of the Emperor of the Imperium of Mankind of the Warhammer 40K Universe. It is quite a lovely speech, and so, it was selected. Anyhow, you can choose what you wish to present to console.

1     use std::fs;
2     
3     fn main() -> Result<(), Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
4         // Reads whole file as a String data type (=90% of simple cases)
5         let content:String = fs::read_to_string("You_Shall_Know_No_Fear.txt")?;
6         
7         println!("x is still {}", x); // Ownership did not move, so it works.
8         
9         return Ok(());    
10    }    
9         let s:String = String::from("hello"); // variable s is the owner of the string data
10         takes_ownership(s);  // ownership of the string data moves into the function
11        // println!("{}", s); // This would result in a compile-time error: use of a moved 
12                              // moved value: 's' 
13                                  
14    }
