A more complicated example is the reading and parsing of a log file. The following example perform this very task.

1     use std::fs;
2     use std::io::{ self, BufRead, BufReader };
3     
4     #[derive(Debug)]
5     enum {
6         Info, 
7         Warn,
8         Error,
9         Debug,
10        Trace,
11    }
12     
13    #[derive(Debug)]
14    struct LogEntry {
15        timestamp: String,
16        eventlevel: Event,
17        message: String,
18    }
19    
20    fn main() -> Result<()> {
21        let file:File = File::open("big.log");
22        let reader:BufReader<File> = BufReader::new(file);      
23        
24        let mut count = 0u64;
25        let mut valid = 0u64;
26        let mut errors = 0u64;  
27    
28        for (index, line) in reader.lines().enumerate() {
29            count += 1;
30    
31            let unwrapped_line = match line {
32                Ok(text) => text,
33                Err(e) => {
34                    eprintln!("I/O error at line {}: {}", index+1, e);
35                    errors += 1;
36                    continue;
37                }
38            };
39    
40            match parse_log(&unwrapped_line) {
41                Ok(text) => {
42                    valid += 1;
43                    println!("Line {}: {:?}", index+1, text);
44                },
45                Err(e) => {
46                    eprintln!("Parse error at line {}: {}", index+1, e);
47                },
48            }
49        }
50    
51        println!("\nStatistics:");
52        println!("Total lines count: {:>5}", count);
53        println!("Valid entries:   {:>7}", valid);
54        println!("Parse failures:  {:>7}", errors);
55    
56        return Ok(());
57    }
58    
59    fn parse_log(text:&str) -> Result<LogEntry, String> {
60        let parts:Vec<&str> = text.splitn(3, " ").collect();
61        if parts.len() < 3 {
62            return Err("Too few fields within Log Entry.".to_string());
63        }
64    
65        let time_stamp = parts[0].to_string();
66    
67        let event = match parts[1] {
68            "INFO" | "info" => Event::Info,
69            "WARN" | "warn" => Event::Warn,
70            "ERROR" | "error" | "ERR" => Event::Error,
71            "DEBUG" | "debug" => Event::Debug,
72            "TRACE" | "trace" => Event::Trace,
73            _ => return Err(format!("unknown log level: {}", parts[1])),
74        };
75        
76        let message_string = parts[2].to_string();
77    
78        return Ok(LogEntry { timestamp: time_stamp, eventlevel: event, message: message_string });
79    }
80

The result of test_prog3 is captured by the following screen capture.

In Listing 2.27 of page 73, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author uses the standard library crate to read a .md file into the following Rust listing Rust program. File is pub struct with private data fields. A pub struct can be accessed from a Rust crate with the usage of the use keyword, but if the pub struct possesses private data fields - those private data fields will remain inaccessible outside of the crate module where it is defined within. In case of File as a pub struct with private data fields, it can be imported from std::fs module, but its data fields cannot be accessed. BufReader is a pub struct with private data fields from the std::io module. Within this example and common applications of opening a file within a Rust program - the File struct is passed into the BufReader struct. With BufReader<File> defined as reader, the read_line() method become available to read the file contains line-by-line. In essence this example program prints the contents of README.md to the terminal.

In[15]:
// Listing 2.27: Reading a file manually line by line

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::BufReader;
use std::io::prelude::*;

fn main() {
    let f:File = File::open("readme.md")
        .expect("Failed to find, or failed to open file.");  // <1>: Creates a File Object that requires a path argument
    let mut reader:BufReader<File> = BufReader::new(f);      // and error handling if the file does not exist. 
    let mut length:usize = 0;                                // This program crashes when readme.md is not present.
    
    // Prints the debug struct of the text data
    println!("reader: {:?}\n", reader);

    let mut line:String = String::new();  // <2>: Reuses a single string object over the lifetime
                                          // of the program.
    loop {
        length = match reader.read_line(&mut line) {  // <3>: Replaced unwrap() with a match statement,
            Ok(num) => num,                           // handles errors more gracefully; error message
            Err(e) => {                               // and assign 0 instead of Panic!.
                println!("Error message: {}", e);
                0
            },
        }; 

        if length == 0 {
            break;
        }

        println!("{:?} ({:?} bytes long)", line, length); 
        
        line.clear();  // <4>: Replaced .truncate(0) with with clear(),
    }                  // which clears all characters from the line variable 
}

In Listing 2.28 of page 73, Mcnamara (2021) [1], author uses a for loop to iterate over the contents of README.md. As in Listing 2.27, the pub struct with private data fields BufReader<File> is defined as reader within the example program. When the read_lines() method is applied to the reader struct as the previous example, it returns Result<usize, std::io::Error> which contains the number of bytes that were read from stream. The read content is appended to a provided mutable string buffer, which can be used within the program to display the content. Applying the lines() method to BufReader<File>, returns an interator - which is an instance of std::io::Lines struct which implements the Iterator trait. As this struct implements the iterator trait, it can be iterated over using a for loop. Although the iterator's yield items are of data type io::Result<String> require an unwrapping method to retrieve the content. As in Listing 2.27, Listing 2.28 is an example of how to print the contents of README.dm to the terminal.

In[17]:
// Listing 2.28: Reading a file line by line via BufReader::lines()

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::BufReader;
use std::io::prelude::*;

fn main() {
    let f = File::open("readme.md").expect("Failed to find, or failed to open file.");
    let reader = BufReader::new(f); 
    
    // Prints the debug struct of the text data
    println!("reader: {:?}\n", reader);

    for line in reader.lines() {  // <1>: A subtle behavior change occurs here. BufRead::lines()
                                  // removes the trailing newline character from each line.
        if let Ok(string) = line {  // <2>: Result the wrap statement here with a let if expression
            println!("{} ({} bytes long)", string, string.len());
        } else {
            println!("Failed to unwrap text.");
        }
    }
}

Rust Jupyter Notebook display terminal output with HTML and CSS, in otherwords, it redirect terminal output to a display. There are some serious limitations to this approach, as the output of Listing 2.28 does not print, despite the code being correct. To bypass this issue, Listing 2.28 Rust code was executed within Visual Studio and its terminal result was captured through screen capture.

Recall that Listing 2.24 introduced the Rust crate regex to assists with the search of patterns with regular expressions, and that Listing 2.26 introduced Clap crate - which is a polished CLI (command-line interface) that allows a programmer the capacity to build their own built-in line-commands. In Listing 2.29 of pages 73-74, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author thought it a neat idea to implement a built-in line command to search for patterns within file and return the found patterns to terminal with a macro print statement.
First step is to incrementally build a command-line argument parser, where the given agruments are accepted and parsed. The first argument is .arg(Arg::new("pattern"), it will contain the regular expression that will be used in the search. Second argument is .arg(Arg::new("input"), it will contain the file of which will be searched. The pattern is retrieved through args.get_one::<String>("pattern") and stored within variable pattern. pattern will be passed into the regex constructor: Regex::new(pattern). Following that, the input path/file name is retrieved through args.get_one::<String>("input") and is stored within variable input. input which contains the file path/name is passed into the File constructor: File::open(input), which returns a File struct that is passed into the BufReader constructor, BufReader::new(f).
As is found in Listing 2.26, the string content is iterated over with a for loop, and each element is passed into re.find(unwrapped_line) which returns either Some(Text line) or None. Placing this expression with a match statement allows for dynamics sorting of cases: in case of a returned Some(Text Line) - it is printed to terminal, and in case of None - a null return () is returned.

In[]:
// Listing 2.29: Reading Lines from a file

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::BufReader;
use std::io::prelude::*;
use regex::Regex;
use clap::{ Command, Arg };

fn main() {
    let args = Command::new("grip=lite")
        .version("0.1")
        .about("searches for patterns")
        .arg(Arg::new("pattern")
            .help("The pattern to search for")
            .required(true)
            .value_name("pattern"))
        .arg(Arg::new("input")
            .help("File to search").required(true).value_name("input"))
        .get_matches();

    let pattern:&String = args.get_one::<String>("pattern").expect("A pattern is required.");

    let re:Regex = match Regex::new(pattern) {
        Ok(result) => result, 
        Err(e) => {
            println!("Error: Regex data types couldn't be created.\nError Message: {}", e);
            return;
        },
    };

    let input:&String = args.get_one::<String>("input").expect("A pattern is required.");
    let f:File = File::open(input).expect("Failed to open variable named input.");
    let reader:BufReader<File> = BufReader::new(f);

    for (index, line) in reader.lines().enumerate() {
        let unwrapped_line:&str = &line.unwrap();  // <1>: line is a Result<String,std::io::Error>, but re.find()
        match re.find(unwrapped_line) {            // takes an &str as an argument, so the following was done.
            Some(selected_line) => println!("Line {}: {}  {:?} ", index, unwrapped_line, selected_line.as_str()),
            None => (),
        }
    }
}

The following screenshot captures the result of Listing 2.29, when the line-command cargo run is README.md is entered.

2.14 Reading from stdin

Listing 2.30 of pages 74-75, Mcnamara (2021) [1] follows the same logical structure found within Listing 2.29, but with two major differences. The first difference is that this program can either read user input from io::stdin() or read a file from BufReader<File>. The second difference is that the string content is parsed within a generic function instead of within the main function; this grants the flexibility to accept string content from either io::stdin() or BufReader<File>.
Recall from Section 2.8.2: Generic functions, pages 58-60, that the generic data type T must be constrainted by a specific trait or by many specific traits, so to enforce specific behavior. If a data type is accepted within a generic function that does not support the behavior expected then suspected behavior will occur, such as, Runtime Errors/Crashes, Incorrect Output or Exceptions/Panics. Thankfully the developers of the Rust compiler thought of this scenario, and prevent it with a compiler error. A Generic function only accepts data types that implement shared traits, such as, Add, PartialOrd et cetera. The generic function process_lines<T: BufRead + Sized> accepts any data type that implements the Sized and BufRead traits. It should be noted that a generic function implicitly requires that the data types be Sized.
Regardless of where the string content passed to process_lines<T: BufRead + Sized>, the parsing and search logic is similar to Listing 2.29.

In[]:
// Listing 2.30: Searching through a file or stdin

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{ self, BufReader };
use std::io::prelude::*;
use regex::Regex;
use clap::{ Command, Arg };

fn main() {
    let args = Command::new("grip=lite")
        .version("0.1")
        .about("searches for patterns")
        .arg(Arg::new("pattern")
            .help("The pattern to search for")
            .required(true)
            .value_name("pattern"))
        .arg(Arg::new("input")
            .help("File to search").required(true).value_name("input"))
        .get_matches();

    let pattern = args.get_one::<String>("pattern").expect("A pattern is required.");

    let re:Regex = match Regex::new(pattern) {
        Ok(result) => result, 
        Err(e) => {
            println!("Error: Regex data types couldn't be created.\nError Message: {}", e);
            return;
        },
    };

    let input = args.get_one::<String>("input").map_or("-", |v| v);

    if input == "-" {
        let stdin = io::stdin();
        let reader = stdin.lock();
        process_lines(reader, re);
    } else {
        let f = File::open(input).expect("Failed to open variable named input.");
        let reader = BufReader::new(f);
        process_lines(reader, re);
    }
}

fn process_lines<T: BufRead + Sized>(reader:T, re:Regex) {
    for (index, line) in reader.lines().enumerate() {
        let unwrapped_line:&str = &line.unwrap();  // <1>: line is a Result<String,std::io::Error>, but re.find()
        match re.find(unwrapped_line) {            // takes an &str as an argument, so the following was done.
            Some(selected_line) => println!("Line {}: {}  {:?} ", index+1, unwrapped_line, selected_line.as_str()),
            None => (),
        }
    }
}

The result for the line-command: cargo run is -.

The result for the line-command: cargo run is README.md.

On pages 75-76, Mcnamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara provides an important summary of Chapter 2: Language Foundations with a bullet point list.

  • Primitive data types in Rust are the basic, built-in data types that are part of the programming language and have the most direct hardwar/CPU representation.
    • Category Data Type Description Memory Size Default Value
    Boolean bool true/false 1 byte (or 8-bits) false
    Signed Integer i8, i16, i64, i128, isize Signed integers means both positive and negative integers Ranging from 8-bits to 128-bits, pointer size for isize 0
    Unsigned integer u8, u16, u64, u128, usize unsign integers mean only positive integers Ranging from 8-bits to 128-bits, pointer size for usize 0
    Floating point f32, f64 IEEE 754 single / double precision float 32-bits to 64-bits 0.0
    Character char Unicode scalar value 4 bytes -
    Unit () The empty data type - represents no value 0 bytes ()
    Never ! Bottom data type represents computations that never return - -
  • Functions in Rust are reusable, named blocks of code that perform a specific task. A function is declared with the use of the fn keyword. Functions in Rust are strongly data typed and require the parameters and return data types be specified. 
    • 1     fn function_name(parameters: DataType) -> ReturnDataType {
2         // body of code:: statements and/or expressions
3 
4     } 
5
  • Rust features are defined by traits, such as, iteration and mathematical operations. A trait is a named set of method signatures that data types can implement, and of which allow:
    • polymorphism (e.g., different data types can be used in the same way)
    • ad-hoc . static polymorphism via generics and traits bounds
    • data type-safe "capability"/"interface"-style programming

      • Most common forms:

    1     // 1. Bacis trait (e.g. like a Java/C# interface)
2     trait Drawable {
3         fn draw(&self);
4     } 
5               
6     // 2. Trait with default implementation
7     trait Speak {
8         fn speak(&self) -> String;
9         
10        fn shout(&self) -> String {
11             return self.speak().to_uppercase();
12    }
13    
14    // 3. Trait with assocaite data type (very common in the Rust standard library)
15    trait Iterator {
16        type Item;  // associated data type
17        
18        fn next(&mut self) -> Option<Self::Item>;
19    }
20
  • Collection data types arrays (e.g. &[T]), vectors (e.g. Vec[T]), tuples (e.g. (T, U, ...)) et cetera, are tailored to specific use cases. In most cases the vector collection data type will suffice, e.g., &[T].
  • Conventionally when working with a binary crate, such as the cargo tool, the main() function is predestined as the single, predetermined entry point of the binary executable. The main() function is automatically called first - via the standard library and linker setup during Rust runtime.
    In more advance cases - especially bare-metal, embedded software, kernal-level, bootloader or custom-runtime developments - the main() function entry point can be bypassed by using #![no_main] (and often also #![no_std]). The new lowe-level entry point can be defined: commonly named _start with #[no_mangle] pub extern "C" fn_start() -> ! { \\code body }.
  • "Every crate has a Cargo.toml file that specifies it metadata." from page 76, from Mcnamara (2021) [1].
  • The binary crate, Cargo tool can compile a Rust's project code code and fetch its dependencies.
  • "The rustup tool provides access to multiple compiler toolchains and to the [Rust programming] languages's documentation." from page 76, from Mcnamara (2021) [1].

3. Compound Data Types

3.1 Using plain functions to experiment with an API

On page 77 of Mcnamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara introduces the concept of compound data types: a compound data type is a data type that can hold multiple values of different data types, which can include another compound data type. In object oriented programming a compound data type is called an object. A compound data type is identified with a single identifier, and allows for the creation of more complex data structures, which act like core building blocks in real-world Rust software.

    The Rust programming language provides two built-in compound data types:
  • Struct: A struct is a custom data type that groups related data fields (e.g. variables) together. It is Rust's primary way to create "objects" with data.
    • Named-field struct (like a record): Struct File { name: String, data: Vec<u8> }
    • Tuple struct (like a tuple with a name): struct Point(i32, i32);
    • Unit struct (no field): struct Empty;
  • enum: An enum (enumeration) is a data type that can be one of several named variants. Each variant hold different data (or none).

A type alias is declared with the use of the type keyword, it creates a new name for an existing data type without the creation of a new or distinct data type. The aliased name and the original data type are fully interchangeable and function the same within a Rust program. With no functional difference between the aliased name and the original data type, a useful use-case arises - where a complex data type can be masked with a simple type alias, which can reduce complexity within a program's code. Instead of using the complex data type to define a variable - the simpler type alias can be used. The following code snippet demonstrates the variety of type aliases.

1     type Point   = (i32, i32);                                  // alias for tuple
2     type UserId  = u64;                                         // alias for primitive data type
3     type ResultT = Result<String, Box<dyn std::error::Error>>;  // common for error handling
4     
5     // Generic alias      
6     type VecOf<T> = Vec<T>;                                     // Although it is rarely ever needed
7
    Key distinctions between type alias v.s. new data type
  • A type alias is the same data type that it is aliasing; both are substitutable. The creation of a type alias allow or result in the creation of new impls and methods.
  • Creation of a new data type (e.g., struct UserId(u64);) allows and grants the creation of impls and methods.

Author Tim McNamara demonstrates the type alias within Listing 3.1, page 78 of Mcnamara (2021) [1], where he aliases the primitive data type String as File. This alias is used by McNamara as a mock file within the example, where File::from("f1.txt") generates a String variable that stores the text file's name "f1.txt". The text file data is not handled within this example, instead that is left for Listing 3.2, for now the file possess no data.
An Attribute is metadata that represents biolerplate code that is later replaced with the biolerplate code during the expansion phase of compilation. An attribute can be applied to a function, struct, enum, module or crate to provide additional instructions to the compiler, compilation tool or Rust runtime routine.
Attributes are written as #[attr] (e.g. outer attribute) or #![attr] (e.g. inner attribute for module and crate scope) and can include arguments such as #[allow(unused_variables)] (e.g. suppressing compiler warning for unused variables), #[allow(dead_code)] (e.g. suppressing compiler warning for dead code - aka used code), et cetera.

  • Compiler directives: #[allow(dead_code)], #[deprecated], #[cfg(target_os = "linux")]
  • Derive marcos: #[derive(Debug, Clone)]
  • Testing: #[test], #[should_panic]
  • Procedural macros: Custom, e.g., from crates like serde (e.g. #serde(rename = "fieldName"))

McNamara introduces compiler directive attributes in Listing 3.1, #[allow(unused_variables)] to supress the unused variable warning from the the unused variable f1, and #[allow(dead_code)] to supress the unused code warning for fn read(f:&mut File, save_to:&mut Vec) -> ! { ... } - which only crashes the program.

In[47]:
// Listing 3.1: Using data type aliases to stub out a type

#[allow(unused_variables)]  // <1>: Relaxes compiler warnings while
                            // working through ideas
type File = String;  // <2>: Creates a data type alias. The compiler won't
                     // distinguish between String and File, but your  
                     // source code will.


// <3>: Let's assume for the moment that these
// two functions always succeed.
fn open(f:&mut File) -> bool {
    return true;
}

fn close(f:&mut File) -> bool {
    return true;
}

#[allow(dead_code)]  // <4>: Relaxes a compiler warning about an unused function
fn read(f:&mut File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> ! {  // <5>: The ! return data type
                                                   // indicates to the Rust compiler
                                                   // that this function never returns
    unimplemented!();  // <6>: A marco that crashes the program if it's
}                      // encountered

fn main() {
    let mut f1:String = File::from("f1.text");  // <7>: With the data type declaration at Line 3,
                                                // File inherits all of String's method
    println!("f1.txt was opened: {}", open(&mut f1));
    // read(f1, vec![]);  // <8>: There's little point in calling this method: program would crash.
    println!("f1.txt was closed: {}", close(&mut f1));
}
main();

f1.txt was opened: true
f1.txt was closed: true

Although McNamara mentions on page 79 of McNamara (2021) [1] that "There is [only] so much that can be encoded in a string", in fact a string can comprise the entirety of a text file, its name and text data. Suppose that a text file were stored in the following format: "f1.txt; 82,117,115,116", where a semi-colon seperates the file name and text data. The string can be parsed to seperate the file name and text data into seperate string literal elements, these string literal elements are collected into Vec<&str>. To remove the extra space characters from the string literal element, .iter().map(|x| x.trim()).collect() is applied to Vec<&str>. With that completed, string_file_data = vec!["f1.txt", "82,117,115,116"]. As is observed the text data is already in decimal bytes, which means the next step is to split the string literal decimal bytes data into separate string literal elements. To accomplish this .split(',').collect() is applied to string_file_data[1]; this results in Vec<&str> where it equals vec!["82", "117", "115", "116"].
To parse the string literal elements into u8, file_data is iterated over with a for loop and the iterated elements are passed into a match statement. Elements that are successfully parsed into u8 are pushed into buffer:Vec. Upon completion - the parsed text data can be converted into String with the assistance of String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer).to_string(). Result was macro printed to terminal.

In[76]:
fn main() {
    // let s:String = String::from("f1.txt; 1,2,3,4,5;");
    let file:&str = "f1.txt; 82,117,115,116";

    let mut string_file_data:Vec<&str> = file.split(';').collect();
    string_file_data = string_file_data.iter().map(|x| x.trim()).collect();
    let file_data:Vec<&str> = string_file_data[1].split(',').collect(); 
    
    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = Vec::new();
    
    for num in file_data {
        match num.parse::<u8>() {
            Ok(number) => buffer.push(number),
            Err(e) => {
                println!("Failed to parse file data.\nError Message: {}", e);
                return;
            }
        }
    }

    let file_name:&str = string_file_data[0];
    let text_data:String = String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer).to_string();

    println!("File name: {}\ntext_data: {}", file_name, text_data);
}
main();

File name: f1.txt
text_data: Rust

On page 79 of McNamara (2021) [1], McNamara presents features that will be built into this example file reader program. Although an example was developed above to reflect that a string can contain the entire contents of a text file, it does demonstrate the limitations of this type of storage. With a strictly string representation, file complexity can only go so far. To remedy this McNamara introduces the concept of a struct in the following example, Listing 3.2.
As mentioned, a new data type grants the ability of the programmer to use the impl keyword to develop a impl block, so that they may create a constructor method and other methods for the new data type. The introduction of a struct named File will grant the ability to create a method for it, that read the text file's data.
Nonetheless, the following is the author bullet-point list:

  • We haven't created a persistent object that would represent a file. There's only so much that can be encoded in a string.
  • There's no attempt to implement read(). If we did, how would we handle the failure case?
  • open() and close() return bool. Perhaps there is a way to provide a more sophisticated result data type that might be able to contain an error message if the OS (operating system) reports one.
  • None of our functions are methods. From a stylistic point of view, it might be nice to call f.call() rather than open(f).

3.2 Modeling files with struct

Listing 3.2 on pages 80-81 of McNamara (2021) [1]; the text file is now represented by a struct named File. The data fields are name: String and data: Vec<u8>; where name is for the file name, and data is for the text file's data. To define a struct without a new constructor File::new() from an impl block, one uses the following syntax: let f1:File = File { name: String::from("f1.txt"), data:: Vec::new() }. To access the data fields of a struct, the data field name is dot hierarchied to the struct named f1, e.g. f1.name to access the data for the name field.

In[36]:
// Listing 3.2: Defining an instances of struct to represent files

#[derive(Debug)]    // <1>: Allows println!() to print File. The std::fmt::Debug
struct File {       // trait works in conjunction with {:?} within the marco to 
    name: String,   // enable File as a printable string
    data: Vec<u8>,  // <2>: Using Vec<u8>, provides access to some useful conveniences
}                   // like dynamic sizing, which make it possible to simulate
                    // writing to a file.

fn main() {
    let f1 = File {
        name: String::from("f1.txt"),  // <3>: String::from generates owned strings
        data: Vec::new(),              // from string literals, which are slices.
    };

    let f1_name:&String = &f1.name;         // <4>: Accessing fields uses the .operator.
    let f1_length:&usize = &f1.data.len();  // Accessing fields by reference prevents
                                            // their use after move issues.

    println!("{:?}\n", f1);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", f1_name, f1_length);
}
main();

File { name: "f1.txt", data: [] }

f1.txt is 0 bytes long.
  • Lines 1-5 define the File struct. Definitions include fields and their associated data types. These also include each data fields' lifetime, which happened to be elided here. Explicit lifetimes are required when a field is reference to another object.
  • Lines 8-11 creates our first instance of File. We use a literal syntax here, but typically structs in the wild are created via a convenience method. String::from() is one of thos convenience methods. It takes a value of another data type; in this case, a string slice (e.g. &str), which returns a String instance. Vec::new() is the more common case.
  • Lines 13-17 demonstrate accessing our new instance's fields. We prepared an ampersand to indicate that we want to access this data by reference. In Rust parlance, this means that the variable f1_name and f1_length are borrowing the data these refer to.

In Rust, a struct is a compound data type that allows for the grouping of related data together under a named data type. This functionality mirrors the functionality of other programming languages, but by default a struct does not possess any defined methods, although they can be added through the use of a impl block. Structs, e.g. struct, are value data types that are stored on the stack memory (e.g. stack memory is a segment of memory within random access memory dedicated for function calls, local variables, control flow, et cetera) and not on the heap memory (e.g. heap memory is a segment of memory within random access memory - which handles dynamic memory allocation), and possess a memory layout that is contiguous, with it data fields laid out in the order of which they were declared within the struct's declaration within code.
A struct can be stored with heap memory, when it is stored within a smart pointer or is part of a heap-allocated data collection structure such as a vector Vec<T>.

  • Pointer/Reference: A reference, e.g. &, to a struct &NamedStruct is essentially a pointer to its location within the stack memory segment of random access memory (i.e. if struct is not wrapped in a smart pointer or part of a heap-allocated data collection). Typically of a 64-bit operating system, the size of a reference is conventionally 8 bytes long (e.g. the same size as the usize data type), regardless of the struct's size. The pointer points to the beginning memory address of the struct's data within random access memory. Manual pointer management is discouraged within Rust programming, as it introduce the possibility of human-error with pointer management, although it is still possible to management pointer manually within a unsafe block. Otherwise pointer management is handled by Rust's ownership system.
  • Size: The size of a struct is determined by the sum total of sizes of its data fields, plus any padding bytes added for memory alignment, which mirrors the size of the data fields for optimal CPU access. To query the size of a struct, the following code statement can be used std::mem::size_of::(). Structs possess a fixed and known size at compile time - this is true - unless the struct contains unsized data types like slices.
  • Memory Capacity: For a standard struct, memory capacity is not a distinct concept such as the dynamic heap-allocated data collection, such as, Vec<T> which have two distinct values: the quantity of elements contained in the collection which is stored in len and the amount of memory allocated to the collection stored in capacity. To prevent repeated memory reallocation instances, additional memory is allocated to these heap-allocated collection data types. The memory that the struct occuppies is exactly its size - no additional memory segment is reserved for it. If the struct owns a heap-allocated data type, such as, String, Vec<T>, then heap memory associated with that data type is seperate, but the struct itself just holds the pointer to that data type's stored data that is located in the heap memory.

Suppose a struct named Point which contains the data fields: x: i32 and y: i32. The main() functon only contains two macro print statements: one macro print statement is to print the size of the struct Point and the other is to print the size of that struct's reference.

In[60]:
use std::mem::size_of;

#[derive(Debug)]
struct Point {
    x: i32,  // 4 bytes
    y: i32,  // 4 bytes
}

fn main() {
    println!("Size of Point: {} bytes", size_of::<Point>());  // e.g., 8 bytes (with padding)
    println!("Size of &Point: {} bytes", size_of::<&Point>());  // referenced struct 8 bytes 
                                                                // on 64-bit OS
}
main();

Size of Point: 8 bytes
Size of &Point: 8 bytes

From the print to terminal the following can be discerned.

  • Size of Point: 8 bytes (4 bytes for x and 4 bytes for y).
  • A reference is 8 bytes within Rust on a 64-bit OS (operating system). On a 32-bit OS, a reference is 4 bytes.

A more complicated example involves a struct where its data fields are different sized data types. For example NamedStruct possesses three data fields: data_field1: i64, data_field2: bool and data_field3: i8. The size of NamedStruct is 16 bytes. i64 has a size of 8 bytes, bool and i8 have a size of 1 byte each; that means that NamedStruct should have a size of 10 bytes. That is not the case, as the actual size of NamedStruct is 16 bytes? But why? It is because struct padding is added to the data fields data_field2: bool and data_field3: i8 to uniformize the data fields to attain data alignment within the struct. This alignment within the struct allows the CPU (central process unit) pointer to fetch the data efficiently and prevents a misread or additional computational overhead from additional memory read of the data.

In[51]:
use std::mem::size_of;

#[derive(Debug)]
struct NamedStruct {
    data_field1: i64,
    data_field2: bool,
    data_field3: i8,
}

fn main() {
    println!("Size of NamedStruct: {} bytes", size_of::<NamedStruct>());  // e.g., 16 bytes (with padding)
    println!("Size of &NamedStruct: {} bytes", size_of::<&NamedStruct>());  // referenced struct 8 bytes  
                                                                            // 64-bit OS

    println!("\nSize of i64: {} bytes", size_of::<i64>()); // i64 is 8 byte
    println!("Size of bool: {} bytes", size_of::<bool>()); // bool is 1 byte
    println!("Size of i8: {} bytes", size_of::<i8>()); // i8 is 1 byte

    // For comparison
    println!("\nSize of num: {} bytes", size_of::<i8>());
    println!("Size of num: {} bytes", size_of::<&i8>()); // a reference is 8 bytes for 64-bit OS
}
main();

Size of NamedStruct: 16 bytes
Size of &NamedStruct: 8 bytes

Size of i64: 8 bytes
Size of bool: 1 bytes
Size of i8: 1 bytes

Size of num: 1 bytes
Size of num: 8 bytes

From the terminal print the following can be discerned.

  • Size of NamedStruct: 16 bytes (8 bytes for data_field1, 1 byte and 3 bytes of padding for data_field2, and 1 byte and 3 bytes of padding for data_field3).

Tim McNamara generated a struct named File with two data fields: name: String and data: Vec<u8>, to represent a file data structure in Listing 3.2, pages 80-81, Mcnamara (2021) [1]. The following example generates an example file with file name and accompanying data; size_of_val() is used to measure the size of memory of which the struct occupies within memory.

In[50]:
use std::mem::{ size_of, size_of_val};

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

fn main() {
    let mut f:File = File { name: String::from("Excel.txt"), data: Vec::from([1,2,4,5]) };

    println!("{:?}", f);
    println!("Data: {:?}", &f.data);
    println!("Memory size of File: {} bytes", size_of::<File>());
    println!("Memory size of File's name: {} bytes", size_of_val(&f.name));
    println!("Memory size of File's data: {} bytes", size_of_val(&f.data));
}
main();

File { name: "Excel.txt", data: [1, 2, 4, 5] }
Data: [1, 2, 4, 5]
Memory size of File: 48 bytes
Memory size of File's name: 24 bytes
Memory size of File's data: 24 bytes

Both data fields name: String and data: Vec<u8> occupy 24 bytes within memory, which sums to 48 bytes for the whole struct: e.g. File.
A String or &str can be converted into an array of decimal bytes. In Listing 3.3, pages 82-83, Mcnamara (2021) [1], the author Tim McNamara uses an decimal byte representation to represent string data within File. Within main() he converts Vec<u8> with String::from_utf8_lossy() into Cow<'_, str>, and then print the text to terminal with a macro print statement. This conversion line was modified in our implementation of Listing 3.3; instead of assigning Cow<'_, str> to text, we assigned a reference to convert it into a string slice &str. Another approach that could have been taken, was to convert Cow<'_, str> into a String with .to_string().

In[75]:
fn main() {
    let sentence:String = String::from("Rust in Action");
    println!("Sentence: {}", sentence);
    let sentence_bytes:Vec<u8> = sentence.into_bytes();
    println!("Bytes representation: {:?}", sentence_bytes);

    let sentence2:&str = "Tim McNamara is awesome!";
    println!("\nSentence2: {}", sentence2);
    let sentence2_bytes:Vec<u8> = sentence2.as_bytes().to_vec();
    println!("Bytes representation: {:?}", sentence2_bytes);
}
main();

Sentence: Rust in Action
Bytes representation: [82, 117, 115, 116, 32, 105, 110, 32, 65, 99, 116, 105, 111, 110]

Sentence2: Tim McNamara is awesome!
Bytes representation: [84, 105, 109, 32, 77, 99, 78, 97, 109, 97, 114, 97, 32, 105, 115, 32, 97, 119, 101, 115, 111, 109, 101, 33]

Listing 3.3, pages 82-83, Mcnamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara does not implement open() and close() functions explicitly in this example, but instead created stand-in functions that return true for these two functions. Within this example he implements the read() function which accepts the referenced file &File and a decimal bytes buffer vector Vec<u8>; the function accesses the text file's data from &File and appends the text file's to tmp. Upon the return statment read() return the number of bytes that were read - as a usize.
Within main() the file struct is initiated using a convenience method with the data: name: String::from("f2.txt"), data: vec![114, 117, 115, 116, 33],. A buffer vector is initiated to read the text file's data into the program, and is passed into read() alongside &f2. buffer is passed into String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer) to convert the decimal bytes representation into a macro printable format. The same macro print statements from Listing 3.1 and Listing 3.2 are used here to display the debug print for f2, number of bytes read, and the text data that was stored within f2.

In[38]:
// Listing 3.3: Using struct to minic a file and simulate reading its contents

#[allow(unused_variables)]  // <1>: Silences warning regarding unused variables

#[derive(Debug)]  // <2>: Enables File to work with println! and its fmt! sibling 
struct File {     // marcos (used at the bottom of the listing)
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

fn main() {
    let mut f2 = File {
        name: String::from("f2.txt"),
        data: vec![114, 117, 115, 116, 33],
    };

    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = Vec::new();

    println!("f2.txt was opened: {}", open(&mut f2));  // <8>: Does the hard work of
                                                       // of interacting with the file
    let f2_length:usize = read(&f2, &mut buffer);
    println!("f2.txt was closeded: {}\n", close(&mut f2));

    let text:&str = &String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer);  // <9>: Converts Vec<u8> to String.
                                                        // Any bytes that are not valid utf-8
                                                        // are replaced with 

    println!("{:?}\n", f2);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", &f2.name, f2_length);
    println!("Text: {}", text);  // <10>: Views the bytes 114, 117, 115, 116 and 33 as 
                                 // actual letters 
}

// <3>: These two functions remain inert for now
fn open(f:&mut File) -> bool {
    return true;
}

fn close(f:&mut File) -> bool {
    return true;
}

// <4>: Read() returns the number of bytes read
fn read(f:&File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> usize {
    let mut tmp:Vec<u8> = f.data.clone();  // <5>: Makes a copy of the data here
    let read_length:usize = tmp.len();     // because save_to.append() shrinks the
                                           // the input Vec<T>

    save_to.reserve(read_length);  // <6>: Ensures that there is sufficient space to
                                   // fit the incoming data
    save_to.append(&mut tmp);      // <7>: Allocates sufficient data in the save_to
    return read_length;            // buffer to hold the contents of f.
}
main();

f2.txt was closeded: true

3.3 Adding methods to a struct with impl

In Rust, impl is a keyword that is used to define an implementation block for a data types, such as, a struct, enum, et cetera, where methods, constants or traits can be implemented for that specific data type. For example, a cartesian coordinate $(x, y)$ can be represented by a struct named Point where its given data fields are x: i32 and y: i32. An impl block can be used to create a constructor method to initiate the Point object. An additional method could be implement to conduct addition between Point objects, as demonstrated in the example.

In[21]:
#[derive(Debug)]
struct Point {
    x: i32,
    y: i32,
}

impl Point {
    fn new(x:i32, y:i32) -> Self {
        return Point { x, y };
    }

    fn addition(p1:&Point, p2:&Point) -> Point {
        let x_sum:i32 = p1.x + p2.x;
        let y_sum:i32 = p1.y + p2.y;
        return Point { x: x_sum, y: y_sum };
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p1:Point = Point::new(3, 8);
    let p2:Point = Point::new(7, 5);
    let p3:Point = Point::addition(&p1, &p2);

    println!("p1: {:?}\np2: {:?}\n", p1, p2);
    println!("p1: {:?} + p2: {:?} = p3: {:?}", p1, p2, p3);
}
main();

p1: Point { x: 3, y: 8 }
p2: Point { x: 7, y: 5 }

p1: Point { x: 3, y: 8 } + p2: Point { x: 7, y: 5 } = p3: Point { x: 10, y: 13 }

In Listing 3.4 on page 85, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara used an impl block to define an constructor that can initate the File object within the main() function. Unlike our example, the constructor method for impl File does not accept argument, and instead contains the initating struct data within itself. And as, with Listing 3.2 the File struct and some metadata is marco printed to terminal, for the reader's/programmer's convenience.

In[71]:
// Listing 3.4: Using impl blocks to add methods to a struct

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

impl File {
    fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        File {
            name: String::from(name),
            data: Vec::from([82, 117, 115, 116, 32, 105, 110, 32, 65, 99, 116, 105, 111, 110]),
        }
    }
}

fn main() {
    let f3:File = File::new("f3.txt");

    let f3_name:&String = &f3.name; 
    let f3_length:usize = f3.data.len();

    println!("File struct: {:?}", f3);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long", f3_name, f3_length);
}
main();

File struct: File { name: "f3.txt", data: [82, 117, 115, 116, 32, 105, 110, 32, 65, 99, 116, 105, 111, 110] }
f3.txt is 14 bytes long

In Listing 3.5 on page 86, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara rectified the issue from Listing 3.4 where the constructor method cannot accept arguments, and where the file is either empty or defined with predestinated data. new_with_data is the new constructor method that accepts file name as name and the file data as data_vec, and it returns File. With this approach to struct initiation, a file's name and its data can be passed into the new constructor, and File will accurately model the text file. The rest of the program logic follows Listing 3.4, where the text file's data is read through a read() method found within the impl File block, and where the read data is appended to a buffer vector - e.g. buffer: Vec<u8>. buffer: Vec<u8> is passed into String::from_utf8_lossy() and converted from decimal bytes representation to Cow<'_, str>, which is stored within text. The same macro print from Listing 3.4 are found here.

In[44]:
// Listing 3.5: Using impl to improve the ergonomics of File

#![allow(unused_variables)]

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

impl File {
    fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: Vec::new()};
    }

    // Alternative approach to the author's
    //
    // fn new_with_data(name: &str, data_vec:&Vec<u8>) -> File {
    //     return File { name: String::from(name), data: data_vec.to_vec()};
    // }

    // <1>: This method sneaked in to deal with cases where want to simulate 
    // that a file has pre-existing data.
    fn new_with_data(name:&str, data_vec:&Vec<u8>) -> File {
        let mut f:File = File::new(name);
        f.data = data_vec.clone();
        return f;
    }

    fn read(self:&File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> usize {
        let mut tmp = self.data.clone();    // <2>: Replaces the f argument 
        let read_length:usize = tmp.len();  // with self
        save_to.reserve(read_length);
        save_to.append(&mut tmp);
        return read_length;
    }
}

fn open(f:&mut File) -> bool {
    return true;
}

fn close(f:&mut File) -> bool {
    return true;
}

fn main() {
    let f3_data:Vec<u8> = Vec::from([114, 117, 115, 116, 33]);
    let mut f3:File = File::new_with_data("f3.txt", &f3_data);

    // <3>: An explicit type needs to be provided as vec! and
    // cannot be inferred by the compiler for it necessary
    // data type through the function boundary.
    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = vec![];

    println!("f3.txt was opened: {}", open(&mut f3));
    // <4>: Here is the change in the calling code.
    let f3_length:usize = f3.read(&mut buffer);
    println!("f3.txt was closed: {}\n", close(&mut f3));

    let text = String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer);

    println!("{:?}", f3);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", &f3.name, f3_length);
    println!("Text: {}", text);
}
main();

f3.txt was opened: true
f3.txt was closed: true

File { name: "f3.txt", data: [114, 117, 115, 116, 33] }
f3.txt is 5 bytes long.
Text: rust!

3.4 Returning Errors

Recall pages 79, 83, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara states that there are two problems with the example program that remained unresolved following Listing 3.3: 1. open() and close() only return true and are not actually implemented with genuine functionalities, which can handle a situation where an error occurs. 2. None of the functions were implemented as methods.
In Listing 3.4 and Listing 3.5 problem two was resolved with the implementation of methods into the example program. On page 87, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara addresses the last remaining problem, error handling and the returning of errors. With system programming languages such as C use return codes to signal the successful execution of a program or that an error occurred while it executed. Within C a function return a 0 or positive values to signal that the function executed successfully, while a function returns negative values or specific error code for when an error occurs [13]. The C programming language possesses a global variable named errno, this variable keep track of the type of error that occurs within a function or program, it is set by system calls and some library functions, it can be passed into strerror(errno) to attain a string representation of the error message [13].

The following YouTube videos are awesome resources to learn about this topic in regards error handling within C and Rust:

  • Title: C Error Handling for Beginners: Return Codes, erno & Best Practices, by CodeLucky: [13].
  • Title: The Importance of Error Handling in C, by Nir Lichtman: [14]
  • Title: Rust Error Handling - Best Practicies, by Jeremy Chone: [15]

Within Rust there are no true Global variables by Default.

  • Rust actually discourages the implementation of mutable global states.
  • Alternatively a constant can be declared with the use of the const keyword. const are always immutable. 
    • 1     const MAX_USERS:U32 = 100;  // always immutable
2
  • Immutable statics with static: 
    • 1     static VERSION:&str = "1.0.0";  // Immutable static
2
  • Mutable globals requires an unsafe block (or safe wrapper like lazy_static/once_cell crates) 
    • 1     static mut COUNTER:u32 = 0; // Requires an unsafe block to read/write
2

In Listing 3.6 on page 88, McNamara (2021) [1], the example demonstrate how system programming error handling appears within Rust. Listing 3.6 is not a complete program example and therefore be execution with Jupyter Notebook or Visual Studio. Nonetheless, the example illustrates how a static mut variable named ERROR can replicate the functionality of errno from C within a Rust program.

In[]:
// Listing 3.6: Rust-like code that checks error

// <1>: A global variable, static mut (or mutable static),
//  with a static lifetime that's valid for the life of the
// program.
static mut ERROR:i32 = 0;

// ...

fn main() {
    let mut f:File = File::new("something.txt");
    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = vec![];

    read(f, &mut buffer);
    // <2>: Accessing and modifying static mutable variables
    // requires the use of an unsafe code block. This is Rust's
    // way of disclaiming all responsibility to this code block
    // comformity to memory safety.
    unsafe {
        // <3>: Checks the ERROR variable's value. Error cheching relies
        // on the convention that 0 means no error, and otherwise a
        // nonzero value means an error occurred within the program.
        if ERROR != 0 {
            panic!("An error has occurred while reading the file.");
        }
    }

    close(f);
    // <4>: Checks the ERROR variable's value. Discerns if an error occurred
    // while the file was being closed.
    unsafe {
        if ERROR != 0 {
            panic!("An error has occurred while closing the file.");
        }
    }
}

Listing 3.7 on page 90, McNamara (2021) [1], is a full-demonstration of a system language approach to error handling and error message management. The example is complete this time and can be executed within a Jupyter Notebook, or within Visual Studio. The example program has a possibility of crashing, due to the fact that within read() there is a if expression that changes ERROR from 0 to 1, based on an error condition. To simulate the error condition, and for it to be random; the following stochastic condition was chosen by Tim McNamara: random() && random() && random(). When this condition evaluates to be true, Error is set equal to 1, where within the main() an unsafe block if expression will also evaluate true - crashing the program. Otherwise, if the error conditon evaluates false, then the program successfully executes and prints nothing to the terminal.

In[34]:
// Listing 3.7: Using global variables to propagate error information

// <1>: Brings the rand crate into local scope
:dep rand = {version = "0.8"}
extern crate rand;
use rand::{ random };

// <2>: Initializes ERROR to 0
static mut ERROR:isize = 0;

// <3>: Creates z zero-sized type to stand in for a struct
// while we're experimenting
struct File; 

#[allow(unused_variables)]
fn read(f:&File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> usize {
    // <4>: random() returns true one out of eight times
    // when the function is called
    if random() && random() && random() {
        unsafe {
            // <5>: Sets ERROR to 1, notifying the user that an
            // error occurred within the program.
            // If the error categorization is good enough, then this
            // error management approach could provide the location
            // of the error alongside it notice to the user.
            ERROR = 1;
        }
    }
    
    // <6>: Read function return 0 bytes
    return 0;
}
// <7>: Keeping buffer mutable for consistency with other code even
// though it isn't touched here
#[allow(unused_mut)]
fn main() {
    let mut f = File;
    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = vec![];

    read(&f, &mut buffer);
    // <8>: Accessing static mutable variable is an unsafe operation.
    unsafe {
        if ERROR != 0 {
            panic!("An error has occurred!");
        }
    }
}
main();

When Listing 3.7 successfully executes, then nothing is printed to the terminal.

When Listing 3.7 failed to executes, then a panic is return which crashes the program, and prints "An error has occurred!" to the terminal.

On page 91, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara addresses the point that Rust as a system programming language does discourage the use of global variables, as they uncut the type safety checks of the language. The following is his full statement on the matter:

Experienced programmers will know that using the global variable errno is commonly adjusted by the OS during the system calls. This style of programming would typically adjusted by the OS during system calls. This style of programming would typically be adjusted by the OS during system calls. This style of programming would typically be discourage in Rust because it omits both type safety (e.g. errors are encoded as plain integers) and can reward sloppy programmers with unstable programs when they forget to check the errno value. However, it's an important style to be aware of because

  • Systen programmer may need to interact with OS-defined global variables/values.
  • Software that interacts with CPU (central processing unit) registers and other low-level hardware needs to get used to inspecting flags to check that operations were completed successfully.

On page 91, McNamara (2021) [1].

Idiomatic to how Rust handles errors within a program is the use of the Result and Option data types to mitigate edge cases that can cause a program to crash. These data types provide a graceful alternative to conventional methods like .unwrap() and .expect(), which panic when failure occurs. In Listing 3.8 on pages 93-94, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara uses the Result data type as a return for open() and close() functions, it contains the File struct upon successful execution of either function, or an error message (e.g., err_msg) when either function fails to execute.
More idiomatic to Rust error handling, the .unwrap() functions were replaced with match statements. Recall the notes for section 2.3: numbers and Listing 2.5, page 40, McNamara (2021) [1]; the Result data type is an enum with two variants: Ok(T) and Err(E). It lends itself to pattern matching through a match statement, and so, a Result<T, E> data type can be unwrapped gracefully within a match statement and retain its intended functions.

In[47]:
// Listing 3.8: Using Result data type to mark functions prone to filesystem errors 

// <1>: Brings common traits and types from the rand crate into this 
// crate's scope
use rand::prelude::*;

// <2>: Helper function that triggers sporadic errors
fn one_in(denominator:u32) -> bool {
    // <3>: thread_rng() creates a thread-local random number generator; 
    // gen_ratio(n, m) returns a Boolean value with an n/m probability.
    return rand::thread_rng().gen_ratio(1, denominator);
}

#[derive(Debug, Clone)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

impl File {
    fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        // <4>: Stylistic change to shorten code block
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: Vec::new() };
    }

    fn new_with_data(name:&str, data:&Vec<u8>) -> File {
        let mut f = File::new(name);
        f.data = data.clone();
        return f;
    }

    // <5>: First appearance of Result<T, E>, where T is an integer of type usize
    // and E is a String. Using String provides arbitrary error message. 
    fn read(self:&File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> Result<usize, String> {
        let mut tmp = self.data.clone();
        let read_length:usize = tmp.len();
        save_to.reserve(read_length);
        save_to.append(&mut tmp);
        // <6>: In this code, read() never fails, but regardless the return read_length
        // is still wrapped within Ok() because the read() function returns a 
        // Result<T, E> data type
        return Ok(read_length);
    }
}

fn open(f:File) -> Result<File, String> {
    if one_in(10_000) {
        let err_msg:String = String::from("Permission denied.");
        return Err(err_msg);
    }
    return Ok(f);
}

fn close(f:File) -> Result<File, String> {
    if one_in(10_000) {
        let err_msg:String = String::from("Interrup by signal.");
        return Err(err_msg);
    }
    return Ok(f);
}

fn main() {
    let f4_data:Vec<u8> = Vec::from([114, 117, 115, 116, 33]);
    let mut f4 = File::new_with_data("f4.txt", &f4_data);

    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = vec![];

    match open(f4.clone()) {
        Ok(obj) => { 
            f4 = obj; 
        },
        Err(e) => { 
            println!("Error message: {}", e) 
        },
    }
    let f4_length:usize = match f4.read(&mut buffer) {
        Ok(num) => num,
        Err(e) => { 
            println!("Error message: {}", e);
            0 
        },
    };
    match close(f4.clone()) {
        Ok(obj) => { 
            f4 = obj; 
        },
        Err(e) => { 
            println!("Error message: {}", e) 
        },
    }

    let text = String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer);

    println!("{:?}", f4);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", &f4.name, f4_length);
    println!("Text: {}", text);

}
main();

File { name: "f4.txt", data: [114, 117, 115, 116, 33] }
f4.txt is 5 bytes long.

3.5 Defining and Making use of an enum

In Rust, an enum (enumeration) is a custom data type that defines a fixed set of named variants, where each variant can optionally hold associated data of different data types, enabling pattern matching and algebraic data types for safe, expressive modeling of states or options. For example, enums are useful for representing a state that take several different variants, which lends itself to matching pattern via match statement. Such as the case with the Result<T, E> data type, which handles errors and can be unwrapped with the use of a match statement.
In this example, an enum was created to represent the variations of geometric shapes: Circle(f64) and Square(f64). An impl block was implemented to add area() and description() as methods to the enum Shape. Within main(), a Shape is generated through Shape::Circle(5.0), where an f64 argument is passed into, and where the newly created enum is stored within a respective variable, e.g. cirlce (Note: like wise with square). To attain the area for the shape, the area method is called: circle.area() and square.area(). To call the description methods, use Shape::description() - it will return a &'static str.

In[21]:
// Example #1 for enum 
// Note: This is the idiomatic rust approach

enum Shape {
    Circle(f64),
    Square(f64),
}

impl Shape {
    // A method that calculates the area of the shape
    fn area(&self) -> f64 {
        match self {
            Shape::Circle(radius) => std::f64::consts::PI * radius * radius,
            Shape::Square(side) => side * side,
        }
    }

    // An associated function (static method)
    fn description() -> &'static str {
        "\nShape enum data type represents two different geometric shapes."
    }
}

fn main() {
    let circle = Shape::Circle(5.0);
    let square = Shape::Square(3.0);

    println!("Circle area: {}", circle.area());
    println!("Square area: {}", square.area());
    println!("{}", Shape::description());
}
main();

Circle area: 78.53981633974483
Square area: 9

Shape enum data type represents two different geometric shapes.

The idiomatic Rust approach to adding methods to an enum is through an impl block, it is also possible to define a standard function that accepts an enum and performs a task, mimicing the functionality of the idiomatic approach. Within this example, the area(shape: Shape) accepts an initiated enum variant, either Shape::Circle(radius) or Shape::Rectangle { width, height } and return a f64 which is the geometric area of the shape.

In[128]:
// Example #2 for enum
// Note: This functions, but it is less idiomatic to Rust

enum Shape {
    Circle(f64),  // Radius
    Rectangle { width: f64, height: f64 },
}

fn area(shape: Shape) -> f64 {
    match shape {
        Shape::Circle(radius) => std::f64::consts::PI * radius * radius,
        Shape::Rectangle { width, height } => width * height,
    }
}

fn main() {
    let circle = Shape::Circle(5.0);
    let rectangle = Shape::Rectangle { width: 3.0, height: 3.0 };

    println!("Circle area: {}", area(circle));
    println!("Square area: {}", area(rectangle));
}
main();

Circle area: 78.53981633974483
Square area: 9

This example reimplements example #2 in the idiomatic approach that is conventionally found within Rust. The program retains the functionality of example #2's program, while allowing for additional methods to be added to the enum named Shapes relatively easily.

In[6]:
// Example #3 - Idiomatic approach for example #2

enum Shapes {
    Circle(f64),  // Radius
    Rectangle { width: f64, height: f64 },
}

impl Shapes {
    fn area(&self) -> f64 {
        match self {
            Shapes::Circle(radius) => std::f64::consts::PI * radius * radius,
            Shapes::Rectangle { width: x, height: y } => x * y,
        }
    }

    fn geo_description(&self) -> &'static str {
        match self {
            Shapes::Circle(radius) => "A circle possesses zero edges and zero vertices.",
            Shapes::Rectangle { width: x, height: y } => "A rectangle possesses four edges and four vertices."
        }
    }
}

fn main() {
    let circle = Shapes::Circle(5.0);
    let rectangle = Shapes::Rectangle { width: 3.0, height: 3.0 };

    println!("Circle area: {}", circle.area());
    println!("Rectangle area: {}", rectangle.area());
    println!("\n{}", circle.geo_description());
    println!("{}", rectangle.geo_description());
}
main();

Circle area: 78.53981633974483
Rectangle area: 9

A circle possesses zero edges and zero vertices.
A rectangle possesses four edges and four vertices.

In Listing 3.10 on page 95, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara uses the enum data type to indicate the type of event within an event log stream of data. The event log that is processed in the example is composed of three events, two of which are defined, and one which is undefined. The bulk of the computational work is found within the parse_log() function, which parses the log event in twine and stores the result within a Vec<_>: it is accomplish this through line.splitn(2, ' ').collect(). The vector elements are stored within two seperate variables: event and rest. The variable event is passed into a match to be identified; if it is a defined event, it is returned with an enum variant Update or Delete, otherwise it is an unknown event - so Unknown is returned. The parsed log event is marco printed to terminal.

In[62]:
// Listing 3.10: Defining an enum and using it to parse an event log

// <1>: Prints this enum to the screen via auto-generated code
#[derive(Debug)]
enum Event {  
    Update,     // <2>: Creates three variants of Event, including
    Delete,     // a value for unrecognized events
    Unknown,
}

// <3>: A convenient name for String for use in this crate's content
type Message = String;

// <4>: A function for parsing a line and converting it into 
// semi-structured data
fn parse_log(line:&str) -> (Event, Message) {
    // <5>: Vec<_> asks Rust to infer the elements' data type.
    // <6>: collect() consumes an iterator from line.splitn() and
    // returns Vec<T>.
    let parts:Vec<_> = line.splitn(2, ' ').collect();

    // <7>: If line.splitn() doesn't split log into two parts,
    // returns an error.
    if parts.len() == 1 {
        return (Event::Unknown, String::from(line));
    }

    // <8>: Assigns each part of parts to a variable to ease 
    // future use
    let event = parts[0];
    let rest:String = String::from(parts[1]); 

    match event {
        // <9>: When we match a known event, return structured data
        "UPDATE" | "update" => (Event::Update, rest),
        "DELETE" | "delete" => (Event::Delete, rest),
        // <10>: If we don't recognize the event type, returns the 
        // whole line
        _ => (Event::Unknown, String::from(line)),
    }
}

fn main() {
    let log:&str = "BEGIN Transaction XK342
UPDATE 234:LS/32231 {\"price\": 31.00} -> {\"price\": 40.00}
DELETE 342:LO/22111";

    for line in log.lines() {
        let parse_result = parse_log(line);
        println!("{:?}", parse_result);
    }
}
main();

(Unknown, "BEGIN Transaction XK342")
(Update, "234:LS/32231 {\"price\": 31.00} -> {\"price\": 40.00}")
(Delete, "342:LO/22111")

On pages 97-98, McNamara (2021) [1], the enum data type is used to manage the internal state of a text file within Listing 3.11. The code structure in Listing 3.11 follows that of Listing 3.5, but author Tim McNamara extrapolates upon the example by implementing functionality to the functions open() and close(). Both functions accept the struct File and then change the text file state, either open or closed. Upon success mutation to the file state, these functions return File within a Result<T, E> data type. The result data type is unwrapped main() using .unwrap(); although there are better approaches to unwrapping, as we have shown.

In[10]:
// Listing 3.11: An enum that represents a File being open or closed

#[derive(Debug, PartialEq)]
enum FileState {
    Open,
    Closed,
}

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
    state: FileState,
}

impl File {
    fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: vec![], state: FileState::Closed, };
    }

    fn new_with_data(name:&str, data_vec:&Vec<u8> ) -> File {
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: data_vec.clone(), state: FileState::Closed, };
    }
 
    fn read(self:&File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> Result<usize, String> {
        if self.state != FileState::Open {
            return Err(String::from("File must be open to be read."));
        }
        let mut tmp = self.data.clone();
        let read_length:usize = tmp.len();
        save_to.reserve(read_length);
        save_to.append(&mut tmp);
        return Ok(read_length);
    }
}

fn open(mut f: File) -> Result<File, String> {
    f.state = FileState::Open;
    return Ok(f);
}

fn close(mut f: File) -> Result<File, String> {
    f.state = FileState::Closed;
    return Ok(f);
}

fn main() {
    let mut f5:File = File::new("f5.txt");

    let mut buffer:Vec<u8> = vec![];

    if f5.read(&mut buffer).is_err() {
        println!("Error checking is working.");
    }

    f5 = open(f5).unwrap();
    let f5_length:usize = f5.read(&mut buffer).unwrap();
    f5 = close(f5).unwrap();

    let text = String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer);

    println!("{:?}", f5);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", &f5.name, f5_length);
    println!("Text: {}", text);

    // Clears the buffer
    buffer.clear();

    let text_data:Vec<u8> = Vec::from([83, 109, 117, 103, 65, 108, 97, 110, 97]);

    let mut f5_with_data:File = File::new_with_data("5f_with_data.txt", &text_data);

    f5_with_data = open(f5_with_data).unwrap();
    let f5_with_data_length:usize = f5_with_data.read(&mut buffer).unwrap();
    f5_with_data = close(f5_with_data).unwrap();

    let text2 = String::from_utf8_lossy(&buffer);

    println!("\n{:?}", f5_with_data);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", &f5_with_data.name, f5_with_data_length);
    println!("Text: {}", text2);
}
main();

Error checking is working.
File { name: "f5.txt", data: [], state: Closed }
f5.txt is 0 bytes long.
Text: 

File { name: "5f_with_data.txt", data: [83, 109, 117, 103, 65, 108, 97, 110, 97], state: Closed }
5f_with_data.txt is 9 bytes long.
Text: SmugAlana

3.6 Defining Common Behavior with Traits

Traits in Rust are used to define shared signatures, and can provide default implementations. A data type implement traits independently. This is Rust approach to "inheritance", it simulates "inheritance" of behavior without the data inheritance.
Our example in Section 3.3: Adding Methods to a struct with impl, uses a struct to represent a cartesian coordinate $(x, y)$. Within a impl block two methods were defined for Point: a constructor method named new() and addition method to add cartesian coordinates together. To perform addition upon two cartesian coordinates (e.g. p1 and p2), their respective Point structs had to be passed into Point::addition(&p1, p2) as referenced structs. The addition method would sum the components of the cartesian coordinates and return a new Point struct. An more idiomatic approach would be to overload the addition operator + using a trait, so that the addition operator + could be used to sum p1 and p2 together.
To accomplish this - the Add trait is imported using use std::ops::Add;. To implement the Add trait for &Point, an impl block has to be defined as impl Add for &Point. The returned data type after the application of the addition operator + has to be a type alias of output, as it is the specified return data type. To specify this type alias, add the line: type Output = Point;. Then the add method can be added to the impl block. The rest of the code follows the previous example implementation.

In[91]:
use std::ops::Add;

#[derive(Debug, Clone)]
struct Point {
    x: i32,
    y: i32,
}

impl Point {
    fn new(x:i32, y:i32) -> Self {
        return Point { x, y };
    }
}

impl Add for &Point {
    type Output = Point;
    
    fn add(self, other: Self) -> Point {
        return Point { x: self.x + other.x, y: self.y + other.y };
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p1:Point = Point::new(3, 8);
    let p2:Point = Point::new(7, 5);
    let p3 = &p1 + &p2;

    println!("p1: {:?}\np2: {:?}\n", &p1, &p2);
    println!("p1: {:?} + p2: {:?} = p3: {:?}", &p1, &p2, &p3);
}
main();

p1: Point { x: 3, y: 8 }
p2: Point { x: 7, y: 5 }

p1: Point { x: 3, y: 8 } + p2: Point { x: 7, y: 5 } = p3: Point { x: 10, y: 13 }

In Rust, std::ops::Add trait and similar operator traits (e.g. sub, Mul, et cetera) uses an associated data type named Output to specify the return data type of the add method from impl Add for &Point. This is part of the trait's definition:

1     pub trait Add<Rhs = Self> {
2         type Output;
3         fn add(self, rhs: Rhs) -> Self::output;
4     }
5

Why can Associated Data Type?

  • Trait Design: Associate data types allow the trait to define a placeholder for a data type that's determined by the implementer (e.g., for example, here, Output is the result of self + rhs). This make the trait more flexible than using generics directly in the method signature (e.g., fn add<T>(Self, rhs: Rhse) -> T), as it avoid cluttering method calls with extra type parameters and improve data type inference.
  • Operator Overloading: It enables a clean operator syntax like a + b without ambiguity about the resulting data type. For example, adding two i32 returns i32, but custom data types might return another data type - which might not be the data types that was inferred by the compiler (e.g., a matrix multiplication could return a new matrix data type).
  • Required by the Trait: When implementing the Add trait for a data type, the return data type must be specified as type Output = ...; to satify the Add trait. In our Point example, the return data type was type alias as type Output = Self;, which means that two Point's returns another Point.

If the return data type were to be different; in otherwords a tuple (e.g. (T1, T1, ...)), vector (e.g. Vec<T>), et cetera, the type alias would be set accordingly to that specified output data type. This pattern is common in the Rust standard library for operations, such as, Sub, Mul, et cetera, which provides composability and readability within the code base.
In Listing 3.12 on page 99, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara implements a Read trait for a snub struct named File. Within the Read trait, he creates a method that indicates the data types for its arguments and return. He then applies the Read trait to the File for a impl block, where he defines the read() function - which reads the file.

In[24]:
// Listing 3.12: Defining the bare bones of a Read trait for File

// <1>: Silences any warnings relating to unused variables
// within functions
#![allow(unused_variables)]

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File;  // <2>: Defines a stub File data type

// <3>: Provides a specific name for the trait
trait Read {
    // <4>: A trait block includes the data type signatures of functions
    // that implementors must comply with. The pseudo-data-type Self
    // is a placeholder for the data type that eventually implements Read.
    fn read(self:&Self, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> Result<usize, String>;
}

impl Read for File {
    fn read(self:&File, save_to:&mut Vec<u8>) -> Result<usize, String> {
        // <5>: A simple stub value that complies with the data type
        // signature required.
        return Ok(0);
    }
}

fn main() {
    let f:File = File {};
    let mut buffer:Vec<_> = vec![];
    let n_bytes:usize = f.read(&mut buffer).unwrap();
    println!("{} byte(s) read from {:?}", n_bytes, f);
}
main();

0 byte(s) read from File

The Debug trait in Rust is part of the standard library, it provides a way to format values for debugging purposes, either using the row-format syntax {:?} or column-format syntax {:#?} of pretty-printed format within a string specificier - such as println! or format! macros - to indicate the desired type of printing. The Debug trait is already implemented for most primitive data types within Rust, but can be manually implemented for compound data types, such as, struct, enum, et cetera, by defining a fmt method that outputs a human-readable representation.
The following example demonstrates both the row-format syntax pretty-printed format, and column-format syntax pretty-printed format of a Vec<f32> vector. Row-format syntax, prints the brackets, commas and elements within the first terminal line. Column-format syntax prints the part of the vector on a new line of the terminal, the print forms a column-like structure, and so, that is why it is called the column-format.

In[40]:
// Print vector in either row-format or column-format of pretty-printed format

fn main() {
    let vector_x:Vec<f32> = vec![1.5, 3.6, 7.5, 4.2, 3.1];

    println!("pretty print row: {:?}", vector_x);
    println!("Pretty print column: {:#?}", vector_x);
} 
main();

pretty print row: [1.5, 3.6, 7.5, 4.2, 3.1]
Pretty print column: [
    1.5,
    3.6,
    7.5,
    4.2,
    3.1,
]

On page 99, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara mentions the fact that various i/o macros, such as, println!, print!, write!, writeln! and format! rely upon the Display and Debug traits. And thus, the style of print that is outputted to terminal dependents on the programmer implementing these traits with the provided syntax, and or, the packaged routines found within std::fmt.
The following example demonstrates the functionality of the write! macro; its purpose is to write utf-8 string text into a buffer vector (e.g. Vec<u8>) in decimal bytes format. The buffer vector can be printed to console with the use of the println! or print! macros, and with the assistance of the row-format or column format of pretty-printed format. In the example, we chose the row-format to print the buffer and its string text to terminal.
Note, that because ? was used to unwrap Result<(), std::fmt::Error> the return of the write! macro, and that the error std::fmt::Error that can be returned through this result data type - needs to be propagated to main() function. To propagate this error data type (e.g. std::io::Error) into main() it has to return a result data type that can accept the conversion from std::fmt::Error. A common choice is fn main() -> std::io::Result<()>, which we chose to implement here.

In[13]:
use std::io::Write;

fn main() -> std::io::Result<()> {
    let mut w:Vec<u8> = Vec::new();
    write!(&mut w, "Test string")?;
    write!(&mut w, ": formatted {}", "arguments string")?;

    println!("Decimal bytes representation: {:?}", &w);
    println!("Text format: {:?}", String::from_utf8_lossy(&w));

    return Ok(());
}
main();

Decimal bytes representation: [84, 101, 115, 116, 32, 115, 116, 114, 105, 110, 103, 58, 32, 102, 111, 114, 109, 97, 116, 116, 101, 100, 32, 97, 114, 103, 117, 109, 101, 110, 116, 115, 32, 115, 116, 114, 105, 110, 103]
Text format: "Test string: formatted arguments string"
