In Listing 3.14, on pages 100-101, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara explains that the std::fmt module lend the capacity to programmer to develop custom text - to display for given objects, such as, File. To begin, the std::fmt module and Display trait must be brought into local scope with the assistance of use. The Display trait then must be applied to the objects that the programmer desire to implement its behavior for; in case of Listing 3.14, an impl block had to be defined for FileState and File which implements the Display trait.
Within both of these impl Display for <Object> blocks a fmt method had to be defined to instruct desired custom text that the used desired to be return, when the object were printed to console through the assistance of Display implemented print.

In[]:
// Listing 3.14: Using std::fmt::Display for File and its associated FileState

use std::fmt;
use std::fmt::{ Display };

#[derive(Debug, PartialEq)]
enum FileState {
    Open,
    Closed,
}

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
    state: FileState,
}


impl Display for FileState {
    // <1>: To implement std::fmt:Display, a single fmt method must
    // be defined for your data type
    fn fmt(&self, f:&mut fmt::Formatter) -> fmt::Result {
        match *self {
            FileState::Open => write!(f, "OPEN"),
            FileState::Closed => write!(f, "CLOSED"),
        }
    }
}

impl Display for File {
    // <2>: To implement std::fmt:Display, a single fmt method must
    // be defined for your data type
    fn fmt(&self, f:&mut fmt::Formatter) -> fmt::Result {
        // <3>: It is common to defer to the inner data type's Display 
        // implementation via the write!() marco.
        write!(f, "<{} ({})>", self.name, self.state)
    }
}

In Listing 3.15 on pages 101-102, McNamara (2021) [1], the author Tim McNamara expands program example to a full-program that can be executed within a Jupyter Notebook or Visual Studio. Within main() a file is generated and named f5. Text data is stored in f6 through f6.data = vec![72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33]. Then two macro print statements were used: one relied on the Debug printed text and one relied on the Display trait implemented custom text that the author developed for File. This Listing demonstrates that custom texts can be developed by a programmer, and that they do not need to solely rely upon the Debug printed text.

In[20]:
// Listing 3.15: Working Code Snippet to implementation Display

// <1>: Silences warnings related to FileState::Open not being 
// used.
#[allow(dead_code)]

use std::fmt;  // <2>: Brings the std::fmt crate into local scope,
               // making use of fmt::Result
use std::fmt::{ Display };  // <3>: Brings the std::fmt crate into
                            // local scope, making use of 
                            // fmt::Result.

#[derive(Debug, PartialEq)]
enum FileState {
    Open,
    Closed,
}

#[derive(Debug)]
struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
    state: FileState,
}

impl Display for FileState {
    fn fmt(&self, f:&mut fmt::Formatter) -> fmt::Result {
        // <4>: Sneakily we can make use of write!() to do the grunt
        // work for us. Strings already implement Display, so there's
        // little left for us to do.
        match *self {
            FileState::Open => write!(f, "open"),
            FileState::Closed => write!(f, "Closed"),
        }
    }
}

impl Display for File {
    fn fmt(&self, f:&mut fmt::Formatter) -> fmt::Result {
        // <5>: We can rely on this FileState Display implementation.
        write!(f, "<{} ({})>", self.name, self.state)
    }
}

impl File {
    fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: Vec::new(), state: FileState::Closed };
    }
}

fn main() {
    let file_name:&str = "something.txt";
    let mut f6:File = File::new(file_name);
    f6.data = vec![72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33];

    // <6>: The Debug implementation prints a familiar message in common with
    // all other implementors of Debug: File { ... } 
    println!("Struct (without Display): {:?}", f6);
    // <7>: Our Display implementation follows its own rules, displaying 
    // the File struct data type as specified: <something.txt (Closed)> 
    println!("Struct (with Display): {}", f6);
}
main();

Struct (without Display): File { name: "something.txt", data: [72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33], state: Closed }
Struct (with Display): <something.txt (Closed)>

As well, as it implication to "inheritance" like behavior when implemented in a certain approach (e.g. in a way for objects to have shared bahavior without shared data).

We'll see many uses of traits throughout the course of the book. These underlie Rust's generic system and the language's robust [data] type checking. With a little bit of abuse, these also support a form of "inheritance" that's common in most object-orient [programming] languages. For now, though, the thing to remember is that traits represent common behavior that types opt into via the syntax impl Trait for Data Type.

3.7 Exposing your data types to the world

In Rust, visibility - often referred to as "public" v.s. "private" - controls the accessibility of items, such as, functions, structs, enums, modules, and more. This accessibility framework is a core of Rust's module system, which helps enforce the encapsulation and modularity of Rust code. Visibility is heirarchical and tied to the module structure, that ensures that Rust code is only exposed when it is desired and intentional.

Default Visibility is Private:

  • Visibility of an item, or items are default set to private. This means these items are only accessible within the module where they were defined and any descendant (e.g. child) modules.
  • There are exceptions to the default private rule:
    • Associated items, such as, methods in a pub trait are themselves public by default.
    • Variants of a pub enum are public by default.
  • Private items cannot be accessed from sibling modules, parent modules, or external crates unless re-exported (e.g., via pub use).

Public Visibility: The pub keyword

  • The pub keyword is used to make an item public. When that item is public, it is accessible from outside the module where it was defined; but only if all ancestor modules are also public. A public item can be reached by any module that can nagivate the module hierarchy to access them or through re-exports.
  • "Public" does not mean that an item is globally visible, it mean that it is accessible relative to the crate and module paths. For example:
    • A public item in a public module can be used by other modules in the same crate or even external crates (e.g., if the crate exports it).
    • However, if any ancestor module is private, than the item remains inaccessible from outside that ancestor's scope.

Visibility rules are consistent across most Rust items, but nuances do exist:

  • Modules: A pub mod declaration makes the module and its public contents accessible from outside itself. Private modules (mod without pub) are only usable by their parent and descendants.
  • Structs and Enums: These data types themselves can become public with the use of the pub keyword, e.g., pub struct MyStruct, but the data fields of a struct or variants of an enum can have their own independent visibility. For example, recall from Listing 2.27 of page 73, McNamara (2021) [1], that File was a pub struct with private data fields, it can be imported from std::fs module, but its data fields cannot be accessed.
  • Functions and Methods: pub fn makes them callable from outside the module. Private functions are only accessible within the module that they were defined in.
  • Traits and Impl Blocks: Traits can be public, but implementation might be restricted. Associated its in public traits default to public.
  • Constants, Types Aliases, et cetera: The pub keyword exposes these items to the hierarchy of visibility.

  1. Private items: Accessible only in the defining module and its descendants.
  2. Public items: Accessible from any module that can reach all public ancestors.

Re-exports (e.g., pub use crate::internal::item;) can makes items available under new paths, potentially bypassing some privacy restrictions by making them reachable elsewhere.
The following snippet of Rust code is an example of a simple crate structure, it is meant to demonstrate visibility in the Rust programming language.
In this example, an external crates can use the following code statement public_api::api_function() to access crate::helper::crate_wide_helper(), but not crate::helper::private_helper() as private_helper() is a private function. Trying to access crate::helper::private_helper() will result in an error.

1     // lib.rs (crate root)
2     
3     mod helper {  // Private module: accessible only here and in descendants
4         pub(crate) fn crate_wide_helper() {  // Visible anywhere in this crate
5             println!("Helper visible in crate");
6         } 
7               
8         fn private_helper() {  // Private: only in this module and descendants
9             println!("Private helper");
10        }
11         
12        pub(super) fn parent_visible() {  // Visible only to the parent (crate root)
13            println!("Visible to parent");
14        }
15    }
16    
17    pub mod public_api {  // Public module: accessible from external crates
18        pub fn api_function() {
19            crate::helper::crate_wide_helper();  // OK: pub(crate)
20            // crate::helper::private_helper();  // Error: private
21        }
22    }
23    
24    fn main() {
25        helper::parent_visible();  // OK: pub(super)
26        helper::crate_wide_helper();  // OK: pub(crate) 
27        // helper::private_helper();  // Error: private
28    }
29

In Listing 3.16 on pages 102-103, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara demonstrates visibility within Rust. He made the enumerate FileState into a public item with the use of the pub keyword. As FileState is a public item, so are its variants: Open and Closed. He also made the struct File into a public item, although it data fields remained private - so as long as a pub keyword did not prefix the data field. Author Tim McNamara also demonstrate public methods; he prefixed the constructor method from the impl File block and made it a public item.

In[18]:
//Listing 3.16: Using pub to mark the name and state fields of File public

// <1>: An enum's variants are assumed to be public if the overall
// data type is made public.
#[derive(Debug, PartialEq)]
pub enum FileState {
    Open,
    Closed,
}

// <2>: File.data remains private if a third-party were to import
// this crate via use.
#[derive(Debug)]
pub struct File {
    pub name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
    pub state: FileState,
}

// <3>: Even though the File Struct is public, its methods must also
// be explicitly marked as public.
impl File {
    pub fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: Vec::new(), state: FileState::Closed };
    }
}

fn main() {
    let file_name:&str = "something.txt";
    let mut f:File = File::new(file_name);
    f.data = vec![72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33];

    let text = String::from_utf8_lossy(&f.data);

    println!("Struct: {:?}", f);
    println!("Utf-8 decimal: {:?}", &f.data);
    println!("Text: {}", text);
}
main();

Struct: File { name: "something.txt", data: [72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33], state: Closed }
Utf-8 decimal: [72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 44, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100, 33]
Text: Hello, world!

3.8 Creating inline documentation for your projects

In Rust, /// and //! are special forms of line comments used for HTML documentation purposes, processed by cargo's rustdoc to generate a rich HTML documentation. These are distinct to the reguler comment syntax, //, /* */ which generate comments that are ignored by the compiler.

/// (Outer Line Doc Comment): /// is used to document the item that immediately follows it (e.g., a function, struct, enum, or trait). It's equivalent to an outer attribute such as #[doc = "..."]. These type of Doc Comment supports Markdown syntax, and so, Markdown can be used to generate elegant HTML rich documentations.
Example:

1     /// Computes the sum of two integers
2     /// 
3     ///  # Examples
4     ///   
5     /// ```           
6     /// let result:i32 = add(2, 3);
7     /// assert_eq!(result, 5);
8     /// ```
9     
10    pub fn add(a:i32, b:i32) -> i32 {
11        return a + b;
12    }
13

//! (Inner Line Doc Comment): //! is used to document the enclosing item (e.g., a module or crate) from the inside. It's equivalent to an inner attribute such as #![doc = "..."]. This is commonly placed at the top of a module file as a mean to generate a description that describes it.
Example:

1     //! This is a library for mathematical operations.
2     /// It provides functions for bacis arithmetic
3     
4     pub fn add(a:i32, b:i32) -> i32 {
5         return a + b;     
6     }
7
  • Scope: /// applies to the next item (e.g. outer item), while //! applies to the parent item (e.g. inner item).
  • Use Cases: Use /// for individual items like functions or compound data types. Use //! for broader contexts like module-level or crate-level overviews.
  • Syntax Rules: Correct syntax must be used for each Doc comment, and they cannot contain a carriage return (e.g. CR) characters. Multi-line docs can continue with additional /// or //! lines.

In Listing 3.17 on page 103, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara demonstrates how to annotate a Rust program to generate rich HTMl documentation for it, using cargo. This example will be let up to the reader to replicate and complete on their own. It is fairly simple to complete.

In[16]:
// Listing 3.17: Adding doc comments to code

// <1>: ! refers to the current item, the module that's just
// been entered by compiler
//! Simulating files one step at a time.

// <2>: annotates whatever immediately follows it.
/// Represent a "file",
/// which probably lives on a file system.
#[derive(Debug)]
pub struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

impl File {
    /// New files are assumed to be empty, but a name is required.
    pub fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        return File { name: String::from(name), data: Vec::new() };
    }

    /// Returns the file's length in bytes.
    pub fn len(&self) -> usize {
        return self.data.len();
    }

    /// Returns the file's length in bytes.
    pub fn name(&self) -> String {
        return self.name.clone();
    }
}

fn main() {
    let f1:File = File::new("f1.txt");

    let f1_name:&str = &f1.name();
    let f1_length:usize = f1.len();

    println!("{:?}", f1);
    println!("{} is {} bytes long.", f1_name, f1_length);
}
main();

File { name: "f1.txt", data: [] }
f1.txt is 0 bytes long.

In Listing 3.18 on pages 104-106, McNamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara demonstrates the approachh to render a rich HTML document for a crate or project, and its dependencies. As with Listing 3.17, this example will be let up to the reader. This example follow Listing 3.17, but moves onto the topic of how the rich HTML documentation is generated. It is suggested that the reader use Visual Studio to complete both Listing 3.17 and Listing 3.18.

In[108]:
// Listing 3.18: Documenting Rust Code with in-line comments

// ! simulating files one step at a time

#[derive(Debug)]
pub struct File {
    name: String,
    data: Vec<u8>,
}

impl File {
    /// Creates a new, empty 'File'
    /// 
    /// # Example
    /// 
    /// ```
    /// let f = File::new("f1.txt");
    /// ```
    pub fn new(name:&str) -> File {
        File {
            name: String::from(name),
            data: Vec::new(),
        }
    }
}

On pages 106, Mcnamara (2021) [1], author Tim McNamara provides an important summary of Chapter 3: Language Foundations with a bullet point list.

  • A struct is a compound data type that is foundational to object-oriented programming. Paired with traits, struct possess a similar characteristic to structs from other programming languages: C++ and Crystal.
  • An enum is a compound data type, which is useful for listing finite states within a program.
  • Methods are implemented for a data type through an impl block.
  • Like in C, global error codes can be used to propagate error codes and message within a program. But this approach can be cumbersome within the Rust framework, and is generally frowned upon within the Rust community.
  • The Result<T, E> data type a gracefull handle errors and edge cases, either with hard-crashes with panic! when intended or gracefull crashes which allow a program to continue executing despite a specific error occurring.
  • Traits enable common behavior that can be implemented to a data type and shared amongst data types, such as, Add trait. Shared behavior amongst data types is similar to "inheritance" of other programming languages, but without the shared data.
  • By default data and items (e.g., functions, structs, et cetera) are made private. Only through the explicit prefix of an item with pub will that item become public. There are nuances to this rule, but generally this holds true.
  • With the correct use of the Doc Comment syntax //! and ///, Cargo can generate rich HTML documentation for projects or crates and their dependencies. It is quite useful.
